search_result.title: COVID in Ventura County: A year of death, fear and hope
search_result.text:
Some people developed symptoms. Some died. Some lost their jobs or businesses.

Everyone felt COVID-19, from Steph Sparrow who shut down her Santa Paula tattoo shop three times to Joel Vitt of Ventura. Both his parents died during the pandemic. He keeps their ashes in his living room in hopes he’ll one day be able to invite their friends to a memorial.

Shortly after the virus emerged in March 2020, Ventura County Health Officer Dr. Robert Levin speculated the pandemic could bring as many as 1,000 deaths to the region. The estimate was ridiculed by people who contended the severity was exaggerated.

A year later, the virus has been linked to more than 900 deaths. The number grows even as vaccines embolden hope the pandemic will run its course.

Ventura County Star reporters Cheri Carlson and Tom Kisken chose to document the pandemic through people whose lives were altered. Some of them relived moments that made headlines — a health official’s decision not to mandate masks and church members who defied public health orders.

Others went through things that tragically became common. A woman juggled cellphones outside her dying husband’s hospital room. A 76-year-old Oxnard woman with a heart condition tried to find hope in isolation.

Together, their stories breathe life, death and even music into the Year of COVID. Here they are.

Feb. 15, 2020: COVID-19 hits home

0 cases in Ventura County, 0 deaths

All Dwight Everett knew for certain is it wasn’t the tequila.

The retired electrician was on the fifth day of a Grand Princess cruise to Mexico. He and his wife had just returned to the ship from a Puerto Vallarta tour of a factory that uses blue agave cactus to make tequila.

They drank only samples. But Everett's body ached as if he had the flu. His head pounded. He woke up in the night drenched in sweat, his back aching so much he blamed it on the mattress.

He sat out the next three ports, anchored in bed.

Everett and his wife finally returned to their home in Camarillo after a flight to Los Angeles and a ride from the airport that felt as if it would never end. He called his doctor and asked for a blood test, certain of what it would show.

Dwight Everett, of Camarillo, was the first person in Ventura County to test positive for the coronavirus. Contributed photo/Dwight Everett

“I thought it was Valley fever,” he said of an illness he contracted four years earlier.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Dwight Everett, Ventura County's first COVID-19 case I was happy that it was diagnosed so I knew what it was. It was almost a relief. Quote icon

He was watching television news a few nights later when he learned of a 71-year-old Placer County man who died after testing positive for the coronavirus. He had been on the same cruise to Mexico.

Everett realized he probably didn’t have Valley fever.

He drove to the parking lot of St. John’s Pleasant Valley Hospital in Camarillo. A health-care worker decked out in what looked like a space suit of protective gear stabbed a swab so deep into Everett’s nose he thought it would come out the other side.

The swab came back positive.

On March 10, 2020, county officials announced lab tests performed at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta confirmed the result. Everett was case No. 1 one in Ventura County. By then he was already holed up at home in isolation, starting to recover.

“I was happy that it was diagnosed so I knew what it was," he said. "It was almost a relief.”

Cruise to Mexico: Second Grand Princess cruise passenger from county tests negative for COVID

Almost. Because the virus was so new and Everett didn't think he had it, he didn't wear a mask on the ship or the journey home. His wife, Burnetta Everett, who was on the cruise too, later tested positive but developed only minimal symptoms.

Everett doesn't know, will probably never know, if he passed the virus to her or anyone else.

“I could have infected a boatload of people,” he said, adding he doesn’t think that happened. “Nobody that I came in contact with that I know of became sick.”

Looking back at the year of COVID-19 in Ventura County The Star takes a look back at how COVID-19 has affected Ventura County since it hit the area one year ago. ANTHONY PLASCENCIA, Ventura County Star

Feb. 23, 2020

A man returning to Los Angeles International Airport from China’s Hubei province is quarantined at Naval Base Ventura County, Point Mugu.

March 5, 2020

Dwight Everett of Camarillo is “presumptive positive” for COVID-19. His test sample is sent to Atlanta for confirmation.

March 17

County officials order many businesses to shut down. Vulnerable residents are told to shelter in place.

March 26: Playing in the porch light

157 cases, 3 deaths, 41 days since cancer diagnosis

John Gahan, of Ventura, played his mandolin nightly on his front porch as COVID-19 started to spread in Ventura County. Contributed photo/John Gahan

John Gahan picked the strings on his mandolin as he played in the porch light.

His wife, Clare, sat on a couch inside their den, a book in her lap and a scarf tied around her head. She listened as she heard the first few bars of “Off to California.” One of their favorites, John played it every night.

The one-man show on their porch started 10 days earlier after Clare’s brother in Barcelona told them people played on their balconies while the city was in lockdown. Hit hard by COVID, they did it in honor of all those working at hospitals and clinics.

John thought he could do the same.

His mandolin had gone ignored for a month after Clare was diagnosed with non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma on Feb. 15. Days and weeks blurred between hospital stays and doctor’s visits.

Read: Coronavirus canceled a wedding and band practice. But these friends didn't give up

Now Clare was at home, her latest chemotherapy administered through a port in her arm and a fanny pack she wore around her waist. They hunkered down inside their house knowing she had little ability to fight off any infection let alone this new virus.

John’s days filled up with cleaning, learning to navigate online grocery shopping, and doling out medicine in between trying to make his wife of 44 years laugh a little.

Around 8, he picked up his mandolin and headed out on the porch night after night.

A neighbor around the corner walked over with his bongos on the third night and kept coming back, playing from the front walk. By the next week, another neighbor started showing up on a skateboard, his guitar strapped on his back.

John and Clare Gahan sit on their front porch in Ventura. Contributed photo/John and Clare Gahan

The three of them jammed from a safe distance, shared some stories, a few laughs and occasionally some Irish whiskey

“It was sort of a connection to the world,” John said.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Clare Gahan We didn’t always feel lucky this year, I have to admit. But I think for us, all things considered, we were lucky. Quote icon

The music on the front porch kept going for three months until the nights got warmer and streets a little too busy. But friends, family and neighbors kept stopping by; sometimes leaving groceries or a book for Clare, a few staying for a short visit from the backyard.

“We didn’t always feel lucky this year, I have to admit,” said Clare, whose last few scans showed no signs of cancer. “But I think for us, all things considered, we were lucky.”

March 27

An Air National Guard team deploys in Ventura County to help with the escalating need for emergency food supplies.

April 1

School districts across Ventura County announce they will stay closed for the rest of the year.

April 5: 'A political action' for God

279 cases, 9 deaths, 97 people recovered

Sylvie Lariviere-Traub closed her eyes in prayer. A red bandana covered her mouth and nose. Black gloves protected clasped hands.

Sylvie Lariviere-Traub thinks the pandemic triggered restrictions that infringe on religious liberties. Contributed photo/Sylvie Lariviere-Traub

The 66-year-old accountant and mosaic artist from Oxnard’s Hollywood Beach sat in a cushioned chair six feet away from the nearest congregant at Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park.

About 300 people came to Communion services on this Palm Sunday — all in defiance of public health orders restricting such gatherings for fear of spreading the virus.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Sylvie Lariviere-Traub It was more than just going to church. That was a political action I was taking for God. Quote icon

“I’ve never been afraid of COVID,” Lariviere-Traub said, reflecting on a service that observed Jesus’s Last Supper. “You could feel love. You could feel friendship. You could feel solidarity.”

You could feel controversy.

Lariviere-Traub, whose husband died of esophagus cancer five months earlier, came for the feeling of peace she believes emerges when people pray together.

She came in support of Godspeak leader Pastor Rob McCoy, who organized the service and protested churches had been labeled as non-essential.

The congregation moved back inside for good in May, staying there despite subsequent restrictions and ultimately a court order to move outdoors.

Lariviere-Traub, a dual citizen of Canada and the United States, took off her mask along with most church members. She kept coming on Sundays, even volunteering to welcome members.

Sylvie Lariviere-Traub prays after Communion at Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park April 5, 2020. Despite stay-at-home orders, the chapel opened its doors from 1 p.m. - 3 p.m. on Palm Sunday for members although church leaders used social distancing practices. Juan Carlo/The Star

Unflinching in her opinions, she offered up her name when journalists came to the church. She worries religious freedoms are being lost. She worries too lockdowns not only wound businesses but mandate isolation in conflict with the human need for contact.

Indoors vs. outdoors: Ventura County houses of worship juggle options amid COVID-19

“It was more than just going to church,” she said of her decisions. “That was a political action I was taking for God.”

April 8

Area nurses worried about protecting their families from COVID move into RVs.

April 11

Nearly one of three renters across the nation have not made their April payments.

April 28: Not ready to mandate masks

580 cases, 18 deaths, 31 hospitalizations

Reading glasses propped on his nose, yellow legal pad in his hands, Dr. Robert Levin revealed the decision that lit up Twitter.

Dr. Robert Levin serves as Ventura's County health officer. FILE PHOTO

Though many California communities and businesses had already passed mandates requiring masks be worn in public places as a partial shield against COVD-19, Levin told Ventura County supervisors he could not do the same.

“There is no evidence that cloth masks plus social distancing is any better than social distancing alone,” said the health officer catapulted by the pandemic into a spotlight that brought both praise and calls of condemnation.

Along with words that made headlines, Levin issued a white paper citing scientific studies with one report suggesting cloth coverings could even increase risks.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Dr. Robert Levin We were told, everyone in the country was told, not to use surgical masks. Quote icon

More than anything else, he voiced fears a mask mandate would increase the use of medical face masks, then in scarce supply.

He said surgical and N95 masks needed to be reserved, even donated, to hospitals for doctors, nurses and other workers at high risk of COVID exposure.

That, Levin said nearly a year later, is the point missed by people frustrated by words they contended gave skeptics who saw masks as an infringement one more reason to place others at risk.

Back in April: Ventura County won't mandate cloth mask use

“We were told, everyone in the country was told, not to use surgical masks,” Levin said. “I felt comfortable with what I had done. It was based on documented research.”

When Gov. Gavin Newsom issued a statewide mask mandate in June, Levin embraced it, noting the shortage on medical masks had ended.

Now, he preaches about masking, social distancing and avoiding public gatherings as sort of a COVID prevention trinity.

His own mask? It’s a paper medical covering worn only partly because it may be more protective than cloth.

We're dedicated to covering impactful issues in your community. Help us continue to provide stories you care about. $1 for 6 months. Subscribe! Get news and insights sent to your inbox. Sign up for email newsletters. Sign up

The fabric ones, he said, fall off his nose.

May 12

Voters cast ballots by mail in a special 25th Congressional District election. Some vote from their cars at drive-thru polling places.

May 20

State officials approve the reopening of indoor service at Ventura County restaurants and many other businesses.

June 8: The pain of dying alone

1,622 cases, 39 deaths, 45 hospitalizations

It was a precaution.

Joel Vitt’s 95-year-old father fell in the room he shared with his wife in a Ventura memory care center. Stu Vitt, a retired pharmaceutical representative who sang in the church choir and umpired his boys’ Little League games, was being sent to Community Memorial Hospital to be held overnight.

A routine COVID-19 test came up positive. He was infected.

It’s what his two sons worried about most as the virus raced through nursing homes and assisted living centers across the country, spreading from employees to health-compromised seniors.

Stuart Vitt, of Ventura, died in June 2020 after testing positive for COVID-19. Contributed photo/Joel Vitt

Unable to visit the hospitals because of COVID restrictions, the sons waited for news from doctors, each phone call eating away more hope.

By the third conversation, they knew their father was struggling to breathe. He was placed on oxygen. He was being monitored.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Joel Vitt I have both my mother and father in a box with some sort of memorial service on hold. That's not the way it's supposed to go. Quote icon

“I think it was the next morning I got a call,” said Joel Vitt. “He passed away.”

Stu Vitt was married for 70 years. He raised two sons and had two granddaughters. He had friends through golf, performances with the Gold Coast Concert Chorus and years with Optimists International.

The lockdown meant he died alone.

“I was able to say, ‘Dad, I love you,’” Joel Vitt said of a final phone call, trying to explain the pain of not being there. "That's probably the biggest tragedy. ... All of a sudden they're gone and you haven't had any contact."

Marilyn Vitt, Stu's wife, contracted the virus but stayed symptom-free. She died at the memory center in August following a stroke.

Vitt keeps her ashes next to his father’s.

"I have both my mother and father in a box with some sort of memorial service on hold,” he said. "That's not the way it's supposed to go."

June 10

Rising hospitalizations land Ventura County on a state COVID monitoring list.

July 3

At least 188 people have tested positive in a COVID outbreak at an Oxnard housing facility for migrant farmworkers.

July 13: Bracing for a shutdown

5,844 cases, 69 deaths, 97 hospitalizations, 12 days since reopening

Steph Sparrow was in the middle of a tattoo when her phone lit up with a text.

“We’re getting shut down again.”

Sparrow had moved across the country and opened the tattoo studio she calls her baby in Santa Paula three years before COVID spread to the county.

Steph Sparrow had to repeatedly close her tattoo shop, Roses and Rivets in Santa Paula, during the COVID-19 shutdowns. Contributed photo/Shana Morgan Studio

She closed the doors of Roses and Rivets on March 13, a few days before the governor and county ordered businesses, including hers, to shut down.

It was the end of June before tattoo shops received the OK to reopen. She started seeing customers again on July 2 after filing the required paperwork.

The text came 12 days later.

“You’ve got to be kidding me,” she remembers thinking. Her next thought: “Well, I’m finishing this tattoo.”

Read: On one Santa Paula street, small businesses see different outcomes from COVID-19 closures

She had about three months of rent and overhead expenses in a savings account when she closed the first time, in March. She drained all of it and then started going through her personal savings. She watched her debt skyrocket from zero pre-COVID to tens of thousands of dollars.

The July shutdown was the second closure. By the end of the year, there would be a third.

At home, she would — obsessively at times — watch the case numbers and positivity rates, looking for signs of hope. She ramped up a new hobby of weight lifting as a stress reliever and made T-shirts and prints that people could buy to support the studio.

Each time she thought the business would have to close for good, something would come along — a small business loan or a grant from the county. She would have the debt to pay off, but Roses and Rivets would survive another day.

On July 13, she finished her client's tattoo. Then, she messaged the other women who work out of booths in her shop.

As Salt-N-Pepa blared, they packed up their equipment and tried to make each other laugh. They said their goodbyes, and she locked up.

She waited to cry until she got inside her car.

Business owner reflects on COVID-19's impact on Ventura County businesses Steph Sparrow, owner of Roses and Rivets gallery and body art studio in Santa Paula, reflects on how COVID-19 has impacted the local economy. ANTHONY PLASCENCIA, Ventura County Star

July 14

Oak Park Unified School District officials decide their campuses will not reopen in the fall.

July 26

A COVID outbreak at a youth prison near Camarillo grows to 26 cases.

Aug. 2: Lost jobs, paying rent

8,442 cases, 97 deaths, 87 hospitalizations, 4½ months since schools closed

Landin Osborne was cooking dinner when his wife Laurie’s phone started to ring.

A principal from a private Santa Barbara school was on the other end of the line. Laurie hoped for a job offer.

Laurie Osborne, 24, and husband Landin, 25, both lost their jobs when COVID-19 swept into Ventura County. The couple also had to call off their wedding, but instead, got married in an outdoor ceremony with just a few family members. Contributed photo/Laurie Osborne

Before COVID reached California, the Oxnard newlyweds had full-time work — Landin in construction at a hospital and Laurie as a substitute school teacher.

Classes went online, and the need for substitute teachers dried up. As campuses stayed shuttered heading into a new year, Laurie worried she never would find a teaching job.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Laurie Osborne There were a lot of moments that I was like, OK, there’s no way we can make rent this month. Quote icon

Landin landed a construction job for several weeks in April, and Laurie started tutoring as much as she could, about six to 10 hours a week. For a few weeks, her paychecks from the school district kept coming in.

“It wasn’t a lot, but it allowed us to pay our bills and pay our rent,” she said. “It got us through the month.”

They had given up entertainment, spent much less on gas and cut their food budget in half.

But in June, when she plugged in their expenses and pay into a free online budgeting program, the two columns didn’t match up.

“There were a lot of moments that I was like, OK, there’s no way we can make rent this month,” she said.

An opening at a Santa Barbara Christian school came along a few weeks before classes were scheduled to start. It would mean a long commute and more gas money but also a consistent source of income.

Laurie picked up the phone and the principal offered her a teaching position. He told her she could take some time, then he asked if she had any idea what her answer might be.

“Oh, it’s a definite yes,” she said. “I’ll pray about it and talk to my husband, but it is a yes.”

Aug. 9

Leaders of Godspeak Calvary Chapel in Newbury Park hold Sunday services indoors despite a judge’s temporary restraining order.

Sept. 1

Ventura County has landed in the most restrictive tier — purple — in California’s new reopening plan.

Sept. 16

After announcing in-person trick or treating will not be allowed, county officials say the guidance is a recommendation, not a mandate.

Oct. 1: Feeding each other

13,100 cases, 168 deaths, 632 active cases

Carmen Obeso lives in the 93033.

The zip code covers some of the poorest, most densely populated parts of Oxnard. It has spawned more than 13,000 cases of COVID, by far the most in Ventura County.

Farmworker Carmen Obeso helps lead a volunteer group that provides food and other goods for farmworkers. Contributed photo/Carmen Obeso

Obeso has worked in strawberry fields for at least a decade. Injuries that triggered an ongoing worker’s compensation claim pushed her out some seven months ago.

The lost pay meant it became even harder to pay rent. She and her two children share an apartment with four other people from another family.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Elizabeth Cordero, on friend Carmen Obeso When she started feeling suffering, she saw it in other people too. She was thinking if we are together, maybe we can have at least some food to give to the families to survive. Quote icon

The story is common in this part of Oxnard.

It’s why Obeso drives a borrowed Ford pickup — nicknamed "Grandpa" because it was made 28 years ago — from Oxnard to North Hills to Moorpark and back to Oxnard.

Wearing one face mask over another, she and other volunteers collect donated potatoes, cheese, meat, vegetables, sometimes shampoo and diapers.

They deliver the goods to farmworkers, often right in the fields or in parks or large Sunday events held outside a Masonic lodge with mariachis playing.

The efforts grew out of a United Farm Workers food pantry in part because Obeso understood many farmworkers like her use so much of their paycheck for rent there is little left for food.

She knew the pandemic meant many field workers could no longer work because they were sick. Those who were harvesting finished their day in the late afternoon when store shelves early in the pandemic were bare of toilet paper and other necessities.

“When she started feeling suffering, she saw it in other people too,” said her friend and fellow volunteer Elizabeth Cordero. “She was thinking if we are together, maybe we can have at least some food to give to the families to survive.”

The more than three dozen volunteers she works with include a nurse and a retired longshoreman. Most of them work in the fields. Like Obeso, they understand they need to help each other to help themselves.

That’s why the program is called De Campesino A Campesino — From Farmworkers to Farmworkers.

Oct. 6

Restrictions on restaurants, churches and many businesses are eased as Ventura County moves into California’s red tier.

Nov. 20

People wait for hours to be tested as a surge in COVID cases worsens.

Dec. 14: A lot of dying, so much love

30,473 cases, 236 deaths, 204 hospitalizations

A colleague stopped Patsy Wright on her way out of the hospital.

A family member got permission to visit a patient with COVID; not in the room but just outside. The patient was dying.

It was around 5:30 p.m., and Wright had a university class to teach at 7. She turned around and headed back to the unit. A clinical psychologist on a palliative care team at Ventura County Medical Center, her job is to support patients and their families.

Patsy Wright, a clinical psychologist, started working on the palliative care team at Ventura County Medical Center in April 2020. Contributed photo/Patsy Wright

Wright talked to the woman outside her husband’s room as other staff got two iPads ready to go. The technology would let the wife see her husband as he lay in his hospital bed, as close as she would be allowed to get because of the risk of exposure.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Patsy Wright, palliative care team member at Ventura County Medical Center Even though I see a lot of very sad illnesses and a lot of dying, I get to see so much love. Quote icon

When it was clear only one iPad would work that night, Wright handed her phone to the woman before stepping back to give her some privacy.

The woman used the phone and the single iPad to talk to her husband. She called family members on her own cell, juggling the devices for what might be one of the last family conversations.

For Wright, the night felt way too familiar. Too often lately, she heard the last words people spoke to each other or listened to pleas to stay strong and hang on.

“Those are the words I take home sometimes,” she said.

She called it overwhelming and also a privilege.

“Even though I see a lot of very sad illnesses and a lot of dying, I get to see so much love,” she said.

That night, she sat at a nurse’s station as a wife played music for her husband over her phone. Wright didn’t worry about the class that would have to start late or the notes she had to write up.

She worried her cellphone battery would run out too soon.

Dec. 15

FedEx delivers 1,950 doses of COVID vaccine to Ventura County, launching vaccination efforts in the region.

Dec. 21

The COVID surge threatens to overwhelm hospitals. A state calculation concludes there is 0% available ICU capacity in the county.

Jan. 12: 'Tired' of death

58,924 cases, 550 deaths, 449 hospitalizations

Jason Contreras, 40, of Ventura, works as a housekeeper at Ventura County Medical Center. Contributed photo/Jason Contreras

Jason Contreras tapped out a group text calling everything off. This year, he wanted his birthday to come and go with zero fanfare.

He worked shift after shift at a Ventura hospital where the number of patients sick with the coronavirus kept climbing. Nothing felt right about celebrating.

For 10 years and counting, Contreras worked as a housekeeper at Ventura County Medical Center. He liked that each day brought a new set of challenges. He cleaned and readied rooms on an intensive care unit one shift, in a lab the next or at the emergency room a shift after that.

Everything became more intense when COVID-19 hit.

Some things changed right away: The sort of burning smell of a new ultraviolet light he used now to combat the virus. The sores behind his ears from the masks he wore shift after shift. The empty hallways and lounges as the doors closed to visitors.

Some changes came later, after the holidays as the sick started coming in record numbers.

'Like a war zone': ICU beds expand, body bags in play as Oxnard hospital faces surge

He waited to clean a room as security staff rolled away a body all too often. The view out his break room window now included a refrigerated storage container brought in for bodies in case the morgue filled too quickly.

On one shift, he heard a nurse ask another for a phone number. Her patient had just died. The other nurse said to wait, because her patient had just died, too. They would have to call for them both.

Contreras struggled to find a word to describe what it felt like in the hospital as 2020 turned into 2021 and January quickly became the county’s deadliest month of the virus.

“Tired,” he said after a few moments.

Nurses were tired of their patients dying. He was tired of seeing bodies rolled away.

Everyone was tired of death.

Jan. 16

COVID deaths in December skyrocket with January on pace to hit a new high.

Jan. 21

Ventura County public health officials say they see the first signs of the surge decreasing.

Feb. 6: Two shots of hope

74,237 cases, 798 deaths, 331 days after emergency declared

Edna Duncan gave up her bowling league, in-person church and Saturdays helping to feed the homeless.

Edna Duncan, of Oxnard, halted nearly all of her community activities because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Contributed photo/Edna Duncan

The hardest thing the 76-year-old Oxnard woman with the heart condition relinquished was the classroom title of Grandma Edna.

For four years, Duncan spent several hours a day volunteering her time as a foster grandparent in an elementary school program for children with autism. That ended, along with everything else, with the pandemic.

Tweet Facebook Email Email this story Share Share this story Edna Duncan on getting the COVID-19 vaccine I said, 'Thank you God and may everybody get their second shot.' And I drank it. Quote icon

She coped by writing letters to her friends and the kids in her class. She joined an online prayer group. She fell in love with the television show, “The Masked Singer.”

“That was awesome," she said. "You see their talent but you don’t know who they are.”

Her hope of returning to life as Grandma Edna took a leap on Feb. 6 when she was jabbed with a COVID vaccine at the Ventura County Fairgrounds.

Her second dose came on the first Tuesday of March. She celebrated with a glass of sparkling apple cider.

"I said, 'Thank you God and may everybody get their second shot.' And I drank it."

Tom Kisken covers health care and other news for the Ventura County Star. Reach him at tom.kisken@vcstar.com or 805-437-0255.

search_result.title: These are the names of more than 800 of the Iowans who have died ...
search_result.text:
Des Moines Register

The numbers associated with Iowa’s coronavirus pandemic come regularly. They appear in our inboxes and on our feeds like clockwork, sandwiched between big box store discounts and emails from friends.

4,706 positive cases one day.

40 deaths another.

Over 400,000 recovered to date.

More than 6,100 lost.

In the routine of it all a callus grows, a protection against what these numbers actually stand for — people.

Behind these figures are storytellers and hard workers, Cubs fans and pie bakers, mothers and daughters, fathers and sons. Behind these numbers are our fellow Iowans.

The Iowa Mourns project is a result of months of research to reveal the stories of neighbors and friends lost to the pandemic. In writing about them, we focused on the light of their lives instead of the darkness of their diagnoses, and sought to chronicle who they were, what they did and how they’ll be remembered.

Iowa Mourns was made possible by an unprecedented partnership of nine daily newspapers across Iowa’s two premier newspaper organizations — the Register, Ames Tribune, Burlington Hawk Eye and Iowa City Press-Citizen of the USA TODAY Network; and the Council Bluffs Daily Nonpareil, Mason City Globe Gazette, Quad-City Times, Sioux City Journal and Waterloo Courier of Lee Enterprises. Journalists from all over the state contributed, ensuring we painted a true picture of how Iowa has changed from river to river.

We remain committed to telling these stories. If you would like your loved one remembered in this way, email me at ccrowder@dmreg.com or submit their name here.

Together, we can make certain the Iowans lost will always be more than a number.

— Courtney Crowder

REMEMBERING:

A

Connie Abegglen, 74, Merrill. Loved the color red whether on clothes or cardinals.

George Abodeely, 83, Marion. Competed in Special Olympics.

Alonzo Adams II, 95, Davenport. Creator of the Slim Jim.

Clifton Adams Jr., 76, Cedar Falls. Raised English springer spaniels and Brittany spaniels at Ada's Kennels.

Doris Adams, 93, Riceville. Enjoyed gardening and hunting mushrooms.

Duane Keith Ahrens, 83, West Des Moines. Served at least four Iowa school districts as an award-winning counselor.

Forrest Alcott, 65, Waterloo. Loved spending time with his great-grandchildren.

Geoff Amble, 61, Cedar Falls. Often found tinkering in his garage, whether working on his Jeep or building furniture for his wife.

Tyler Amburgey, 29, Dubuque. A Texas native who played hockey with the Dubuque Fighting Saints.

Marilyn June Andersen, 90, Center Point. Spunky with a penchant for everything leopard-print.

Paul Andersen, 78, Sioux City. Active in Via de Cristo for more than 40 years, often serving as rector.

Annabelle Anderson, 79, Council Bluffs. Worked for Congressman Jim Ross Lightfoot for 12 years.

Edith Elida Anderson, 95, Coralville. Proud of her Swedish heritage.

Joan Anderson, 89, Quad Cities. Knit hats for newborn babies at the Bettendorf hospital.

Keith Wayne Anderson, 73, Kalona. Served in Vietnam as a sergeant during the Tet Offensive.

Martha Anderson, 89, Cedar Falls. Worked at the University of Northern Iowa's Rod Library for 31 years.

Leora Andorf, 92, Cedar Falls. Contributed her finest homegrown plants to organizations for annual plant sales.

Gene Andrews, 83, Anita. Owner and editor of the Anita Tribune for half a century.

Mitchell Andrews, 90, Iowa City. A pianist who played solo, with orchestras and as a chamber musician across the U.S. and abroad.

Patricia Androy, 58, Dunlap. Worked as a registered nurse at a nursing home.

Jose Andrade-Garcia, 62, Marshalltown. Was days away from retiring from JBS Swift & Co. meatpacking plant.

Siddiq Mohamed Arab, 83, Waterloo. Worked as a ship's surgeon sailing the eastern coast of Africa before becoming a pediatrician.

search_result.title: Delphi murders: What we know and don't know 5 years after Abby ...
search_result.text:
Five years after the slayings of two Indiana girls, who went for a walk in the woods on a warm February day, police announced an update to the case.

Abigail Williams, 13, and Liberty German, 14, never returned to a prearranged pickup spot after their walk on the Delphi Historic Trails on the afternoon of Feb. 13, 2017.

Searchers found their bodies the next morning — Valentine's Day — in a wooded area not far from the Monon High Bridge, which they had visited the day before, according to evidence from the crime.

On Monday, police announced that Richard Allen, 50, of Delphi, was arrested and charged with two counts of murder in the deaths of Libby and Abby. Doug Carter, superintendent of the Indiana State Police, added the probable cause affidavit remains sealed.

'Hiding in plain sight':Libby German's grandparents react to murder charges

Kelsi German, Libby's older sister, tweeted Friday morning, "Just know how grateful I am for all of you. No comments for now, any questions please refer to the Carroll county prosecutor's office. There is tentatively a press conference Monday at 10 am. We will say more then.

"Today is the day," she wrote.

The girls' slayings as well as the blizzard of news coverage, social media speculation and bits of chilling evidence released in the case, have tormented and captivated Hoosiers and other Americans even this many years after the crimes.

In July of 2021, Carroll County imposed a total blackout on releasing any information about possible persons of interest in the investigation, according to Carroll County Sheriff Tobe Leazenby.

Here's a closer look at what we know about what took place that day on that lonely trail.

Who were Abigail Williams and Liberty German?

Abby and Libby were friends and eighth-graders at Delphi Community Middle School, before they were killed.

To honor them, family members initially thought about raising money for new bleachers or a scoreboard at a softball field where the girls played. Their idea grew into the L&A Park Foundation, a nonprofit created to oversee the construction of a $1 million park, including three ball fields, an amphitheater and playgrounds.

Construction began in the spring of 2019 on the 20-acre Abby and Libby Memorial Park and it opened for play in July of 2021.

Delphi murders early timeline:The search for Abby and Libby’s killer

Who is Richard Allen?

For years police officers and family members have decried the rampant rumors that have circulated in the case as well as the side-by-side photos comparing actual persons to the police sketches that some people have posted on social media sites, saying such speculation doesn't help the investigation and can be harmful to others.

The arrest of Richard Allen only further illustrates that message, as many noted his name has not been one of the many discussed previously on social media or podcasts.

Police have not released any information on Allen's arrest or his background at this time. During Monday's press conference, police and the prosecutor's office repeatedly said "today is not the day" for releasing details of the investigation, the arrest or the suspect.

Allen has entered a 'not guilty' plea

Allen worked at the local CVS as a licensed pharmacy technician and has seemingly been hiding in plain sight as police have previously suspected.

Libby's grandmother, Becky Patty, told reporters that Allen had processed photos of the girls at a local drug store and did not charge the family for the cost.

WRTV's Kara Kenney reported that CVS issued a statement, which can be seen in the tweet below.

'The pain isn't less':Five years after their murder, Delphi teens still mourned

What lead to this Delphi case announcement

The self-imposed blackout on releasing information about the case to the media highlights the importance of Friday's announcement.

While there have been no official statements or updates on the investigation prior to the planned press conference, a podcast devoted to murder mysteries questioned in September whether a recent visit to Peru, Ind., by the superintendent of the Indiana State Police had anything to do with the unsolved murders of two Delphi teenagers.

The hosts of the true-crime podcast The Murder Sheet, Áine Cain and Kevin Greenlee, reportedly took photographs of ISP investigators in and near the Wabash River, near Peru, Ind., about 40 miles from where the teenagers were found killed five years ago.

Wabash River search'The Murder Sheet' podcast: Could water search be linked to Delphi murder investigation?

What is next in the Delphi case

Delphi police and the prosecutor's office said a public court hearing will be set to determine if the documents, including the affidavit in the case, will remain under seal.

Allen, who has entered a preliminary plea of not guilty, will appear in court on Jan. 13 for a pre-trial hearing.

His trial is tentatively set to begin on March 20.

How were the Delphi girls killed?

Social media groups dedicated to the case have speculated for years about how the girls were killed, but that information has never been publicly released.

Police officials and prosecutors have remained tightlipped about the investigation, saying repeatedly that they need to withhold certain key details to maintain the integrity of the case.

"When we have the person we want, we want to know what they know about the case," Sgt. Kim Riley of the Indiana State Police, said in an interview with IndyStar in 2020. "That's why we've held back on the information that we've given out."

Families speak about Delphi murders:Four years later, family says it's 'like it happened yesterday'

Investigation of Ron Logan

In May of 2022, The Murder Sheet Podcast published and affidavit that the Journal & Courier confirmed to be authentic.

The affidavit indicates that Logan, who died in January 2022, lied to investigators.

It also indicated that Logan asked his cousin the morning of Feb. 14, 2017, to tell police — if asked — that he picked up Logan at his house between 2 and 2:30 p.m. Feb. 13, 2017, and drove to an aquarium store in Lafayette.

For more on Ron Logan, including quotes from an interview conducted just days after the killings, click the link below.

Delphi murders update on Ron Logan:Possible suspect in Delphi murders been on police radar since the killings

Who is 'anthony_shots'?

In the course of the investigation in December 2021, police uncovered an online profile used to communicate with young girls, using the name anthony_shots. The man's photo used on the profile is not a person of interest.

The online profile was used from 2016-17, police said, to solicit nude images from juvenile girls.

Kegan Kline was named by police as the suspect behind the catfish account. Kline is a suspect in a Miami County child exploitation and child pornography case.

"During Kegan’s interview," the 2020 affidavit stated, "he initially denied creating fake social media accounts and talking to underage girls. Later in the interview, he admitted to creating the anthony_shots profile and speaking to underage girls."

Kegan Kline affidavit:Affidavit links man to fictitious social media profile cited in Delphi murder investigation

Who is Kegan Kline?

The probable cause affidavit for Kline's 30 charges in Miami County indicated police first interviewed him on Feb. 25, 2017 — 12 days after the girls were killed.

HLN reporter Barbara MacDonald reported she spoke with Kline in December after the Indiana State Police indicated Kline's social media profile "anthony_shots" was of interest in the killings.

MacDonald asked why the state police focused on Kline's catfish social media profile.

“I have not a clue," Kline told HLN. “I think it’s because they said I was the last person to talk to her, is what they told me.”

In March of 2022, nearly 200 pages of police interview transcripts with Kline were reportedly uncovered by The Murder Sheet podcast after they were accidentally posted to a county website, according to Fox59.

In them, police question Kline about communications the 'anthony_shots' profile had with Liberty German the night before she died, and plans to meet up with her the day she was murdered.

In an August 2020 interview transcript, police tell Kline they believe individuals other than Kline had access to "anthony_shots."

In the HLN interview, FOX59 reported, Kline also said ISP reportedly told him “they knew it was my dad” that killed the teenagers.

Keegan Kline police interviews:Transcript refers to conversations 'anthony_shots' had with murdered Delphi teen

Investigators are asking anyone who may have communicated with, met or attempted to meet the person connected with the profile to email abbyandlibbytip@cacoshrf.com or call 765-822-3535.

Is James Brian Chadwell a suspect?

One person who garnered attention surrounding the case was James Brian Chadwell II, a 42-year-old Lafayette resident accused of kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 9-year-old girl in April, 2021.

A knock on Chadwell's door by police officers interrupted his sexual assault of the girl he had locked in his basement, forcing him to quickly dress and answer the door, according to prosecutors.

James Brian Chadwell:Lafayette girl found in basement says Chadwell sexually assaulted her, affidavit shows

After the arrest, residents were quick to point out the nature of the alleged crimes and a resemblance to the first suspect sketch.

"The information has obviously been shared with us, and our investigators are looking into him," Leazenby said.

Attempts to follow up on the investigation into Chadwell's possible connection were prevented when police imposed the information blackout in July.

Since his arrest, Chadwell has been involved in a jailhouse fight, and requested a change of venue citing worldwide media attention.

"Mr. Chadwell continues to be associated with Abigail Williams and Liberty German's killings," his attorney Shay Hughes said, noting that the New York Posts published information that indicated Chadwell is guilty.

Good Morning America keeps Delphi murders in spotlight

On Feb. 10, 2022, the national show 'Good Morning America' featured the case ahead of the five-year anniversary. They discussed the latest statements from ISP Superintendent Doug Carter and family members.

"My resolve to catch him is as strong now as it was day one," Carter said. "The only difference between now and day one is we know about you, a lot about you. Today could be the day. Sleep well."

What else do we know about the Delphi murders?

Investigators have released these four bits of key evidence in the case.

• FBI description: The suspected killer is thought to be a white man who weighs between 180 and 200 pounds and stands between 5 feet, 6 inches tall and 5 feet, 8 inches tall. He has been described as wearing blue jeans, a blue jacket or coat and a hoodie.

• Police sketches: There were two police sketches released in the case.State Police released an image done by an FBI sketch artist on July 17, 2017, that showed an older-looking man with a goatee, who was wearing a cap and a hoodie. On April 22, 2019, State Police released a new sketch of the suspect,one in which the suspect is clean-shaven and looks to be much younger than the earlier sketch. Police say the new sketch takes precedence over the old one and added that the killer is now thought to be between the ages of 18 and 40 — but may appear younger than his true age.

• Smartphone image, audio: A day after the girls were found, police released a grainy image of the suspect taken from video on Libby's smartphone. A week later, they released audio of a man's voice saying "down the hill." The longer version of the same smartphone video released in 2019 shows the gait of the man as he was walking on the bridge — as well as a longer version of audio, where he can be heard saying "Guys ... Down the hill."

• Location of suspect: At the same April 2019 press conference, Doug Carter, superintendent of the State Police, said new information leads investigators to believe that the killer is from Delphi, and they believe he either still lives or works in Delphi, or frequently visits the area.

Delphi murders:Is Abby and Libby’s killer one of Delphi’s own? ISP says, yes

What have their families said?

Mike Patty, the grandfather of Liberty German, has spoken out publicly at news conferences and in interviews with the media about the toll that the case has taken.

Patty said in an interview in February 2018 that he was still optimistic that there would be a break in the case. Finding the killer, he said, would allow his family — and Abby's mother, Anna — to finally start to grieve.

"This is what you wake up with every day. It’s the last thoughts before you go to bed. And some nights, I still don’t sleep. For three months, I didn’t sleep,” Patty said in 2018.

“And I’m not going to sleep until I know another family won’t have to go through this, like we are right now.”

'Horrible to live like this':Family members and community still torn apart a year after Abby and Libby were killed

Kelsi German has said she considered her younger sister, Libby, to be her best friend. She dropped Libby and Abby off near the Monon High Bridge trail early in the afternoon of Feb. 13, 2017.

Finding their killer has become a calling for her. In February 2020, on the third anniversary of their murders, Kelsi posted this poignant message to her 14,000-plus Twitter followers at @libertyg_sister: “Today 3 years ago,” she wrote, “was my last real day with my best friend and I wish I would’ve done it differently. I miss you.”

Kelsi talked more with a reporter from Lafayette Journal & Courier about how special her sister was — and her recollections of the events of that fateful day.

Are police holding a Delphi murders news conference this year?

Indiana State Police announced they plan a news conference to update the investigation of the Delphi murders and who might have killed Libby German and Abby Williams on Feb. 13, 2017.

The press conference is planned for 10 a.m. Monday morning at the Delphi United Methodist Church. Follow us here and on our social media accounts as we keep you updated with latest.

Are Delphi murders a cold case? After 3 years with no arrests, police say case isn't cold

How many officers are working the case now?

The State Police news release said there were two Carroll County detectives, two Indiana State Police detectives "and other law enforcement officers" assigned to the case.

There were hundreds of officers and volunteers helping out in the days and weeks after the girls disappeared and their bodies were found, but now much fewer are working actively on the case.

Police also say they've received tens of thousands of tips in the case. State Police Supt. Doug Carter and other law-enforcement officials have insisted in the past that the Delphi Murders investigation is not a cold case.

Is there new evidence in the case?

No new official evidence, but an augmented reality smartphone app called CrimeDoor released a video based on evidence from the crime scene that gives users a closeup view of computer-generated images of the girls standing on the Monon High Bridge, as the killer slowly approaches them across the abandoned, weather-beaten rail trestle.

CrimeDoor app:Augmented reality app might help find Delphi teens' killer

The free portion of the app lets users access news accounts of crimes. If they want to digitally walk through a crime scene, users must pay $1.99 to download the augmented reality portion of the case.

Kelsi German, Libby's older sister, has expressed support for the app, saying it may "hopefully solve cases and get arrests for many unsolved cases.”

'Down the Hill' and other podcasts about the Delphi murders

The unsolved murders of Abby and Libby have been the subject of a several true crime podcasts. One of the most prominent was launched by HLN, formerly CNN Headline News, that premiered on Feb. 5, 2020, prior to the third anniversary of the girls' deaths.

"Down the Hill: The Delphi Murders" examined the slayings' impact on the small town , as well as how the case continues to haunt the community.

'Down the Hill':HLN explores Delphi murders in new podcast

One of the top true-crime podcasts, "My Favorite Murder," gave their take on the case in Episode 235.

"Casefile" did an hour-long episode on the case, "Unsolved" released a 90-minute episode recapping the murders, while "Scene of the Crime: Delphi" did a 7-episode series on the basics of the case in early 2020.

Are tips still being taken in the case?

Yes. Investigators are still seeking information and ask that people who reach out to them provide key details, such as a name, age, phone number, and why the caller thinks that person may be connected to the case. Such tips can be made anonymously and there is a significant reward for information leading to an arrest in the case.

Anyone with such information is urged to call the Delphi homicide tip line at 844-459-5786. Tips also may be emailed to abbyandlibbytip@cacoshrf.com.

Lafayette Journal & Courier reporters Ron Wilkins and Dave Bangert contributed to this story.

Dwight Adams is a digital producer on Gannett's Midwest Digital Optimization team. He can be reached on Twitter @hdwightadams.

search_result.title: Upcoming concerts in Phoenix: Post Malone, Kesha, Macklemore ...
search_result.text:
Yes, it's almost summer, but there are still plenty of concerts left to see before we head into another season, from Post Malone to Kesha with Macklemore, and Maroon 5.

Here's a look at those and other highlights of the season.

6/5: Ray LaMontagne and Neko Case

The Grammy-winning singer-songwriter is touring on "Part Of The Light," his seventh album. Five of his previous albums have gone Top 10 on the Billboard rock chart, with 2010's "God Willin’ & the Creek Don’t Rise" winning Best Folk Album at the Grammys.

Case is also touring on a new release, "Hell-On." Half the album was recorded with Bjorn Yttling of Peter Bjorn & John co-producing in Stockholm, Sweden. Guests include Beth Ditto, Mark Lanegan, k.d. Lang, AC Newman, Eric Bachmann and Kelly Hogan.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Tuesday, June 5. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $39.50-$292.50 livenation.com.

6/6: The Adventures of Kesha and Macklemore

Kesha topped the charts last year with "Rainbow," her first album back from an ugly legal battle with former producer Dr. Luke, for which she earned two Grammy nominations. She also turned in this year's water-cooler moment at the ceremony.

Macklemore debuted at No. 2 with "Gemini," his first solo effort in 12 years, which included the platinum single “Glorious,” a song whose viral video has been viewed more than 95 million times.

So that's what they've done for us lately.

Details: 7 p.m. Wednesday, June 6. Ak-Chin Pavilion, 2121 N. 83rd Ave., Phoenix. $30.50-$767. 602-254-7200, livenation.com.

6/6: Minus the Bear

These guys have been rocking the prog side of the indie trenches since 2001, earning a five-star review from Alternative Press in 2005 for a second album called “Menos el Oso.”

They’re touring on “Voids," an album Drowned in Sound hailed as a “testament to a band who have never rested in their creativity, and have managed to rebuild and recreate while holding at their core the things that made them brilliant 15 years ago.”

Details: 7 p.m. Wednesday, June 6. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $28-$58. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

6/7: Maroon 5

Led by Adam Levine of NBC's "The Voice," these pop-rock veterans are heading to Phoenix in support of "Red Pill Blues," which hit the streets last year and added two double-platinum singles to their hit list – "Don't Wanna Know" and "What Lovers Do."

Other hits of note include the six-times platinum "Moves Like Jagger," "Payphone," "One More Night" and "Sugar." If you're going, don't be late. They've been opening shows with "Moves Like Jagger."

Details: 7:30 p.m. Thursday, June 7. Talking Stick Resort Arena, 201 E. Jefferson St., Phoenix. $44.75-$1,279. 602-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

6/8: Huevos Revueltos Tour

Two of the most successful Latin pop-rock groups of the 80’s and 90’s, Enanitos Verdes and Hombres G, are joining forces on the Huevos Revueltos Tour.

Billboard says the tour "is likely to be a family affair for audiences," adding, "The music of the rock-pop band from Argentina and the Spanish boy band headed by heartthrob David Summers have both had staying power since their respective debuts in the 1980s.

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, June 8. Comerica Theatre, 400 W. Washington St., Phoenix. $69.50-$350 livenation.com.

6/8: Blue October

Led by singer Justin Furstenfeld, the Houston alternative-rockers topped the rock charts in 2016 with their latest album, “Home.”

“’Sway’ was about finding inner peace and learning to live in a healthy way,” says Furstenfeld. “‘Home’ is about what we do with our time on earth, how we’re going to utilize that time in a positive way and make it the best we possibly can.”

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, June 8. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $28. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/8: Alan Parsons Live Project

Parsons began his career as an assistant engineer at Abbey Road, where he worked on the Beatles' final albums and became one of the most sought-after names in the recording industry for his engineering work on Pink Floyd’s “The Dark Side of the Moon.”

After earning accolades for his work behind the glass, he formed the Alan Parsons Project, a multi-platinum selling progressive rock band featuring Parsons, his collaborator Eric Woolfson and a rotating cast of studio musicians.

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, June 8. Celebrity Theatre, 440 N. 32nd St., Phoenix. $43.01-$97.31. 602-267-1600, celebritytheatre.com.

6/9: Sleep

These doom-metal legends from San Jose have been hailed as "perhaps the ultimate stoner rock band” by a critic at All Music. And the legacy they’d carved out by the time of their late-‘90s breakup speaks volumes to why someone would suggest that.

They’ve played sporadically since reuniting in 2009 and word on the street is that they’re almost done recording their first album since “Dopesmoker,” a song about weed that lumber its way through the sludge for more than an hour without seeming overly long.

Details: 8 p.m. Saturday, June 9. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $25. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/9: Justin Townes Earle

Last year's "Kids in the Street" is as timeless a singer-songwriter album as anyone's released this century – so good, in fact, that if you don't know who his dad is, I'd suggest you Google it because he doesn't need that in his press kit anymore.

Highlights range from an opening track titled "Champagne Corolla" that rocks with the horn-driven swagger of an old Chess Records 45 to the playfully Dylanesque charms of the organ-rocking "Short Hair Woman."

Details: 7:30 p.m. Saturday, June 9. MIM Music Theater, Musical Instrument Museum, 4725 E. Mayo Blvd., Phoenix. $40.50-$45.50. 480-478-6000, mim.org.

6/10: Yardbirds

In addition to launching the careers of Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page and Jeff Beck, these Rock and Roll Hall of Famers were on the forefront of the psychedelic revolution, with singles as timeless as "For Your Love," "Hear Full of Soul" and "Shapes of Things."

The only member of the '60s lineup still on board is drummer Jim McCarty. He's joined by lad guitarist Johnny A, bassist Kenny Aaronson, singer/blues harpist/percussionist Myke Scavone and singer-guitarist John Idan.

Details: 8 p.m. Sunday, June 10. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $34-$49. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/12: Flatbush Zombies

Brooklyn rappers Meechy Darko, Zombie Juice and Erick "The Architect" Elliott are back on the road in support of "Vacation in Hell," their much-anticipated followup to “3001: A Laced Odyssey.”

There’s a heavy psychedelic vibe to Flatbush Zombies’ hip-hop, from the sound to lyrics celebrating acid (“Acid, Acid, change yo’ life”). HipHopDX called "3001" a "hodgepodge of haunting strings, ambient sounds fit for a sci-fi film and hard-hitting drums.”

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, June 12. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $26-$99. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

6/12: Nightmares on Wax

The British DJ less commonly known as George Evelyn hits Phoenix in support of "Shape the Future," his latest release on Warp Records. The music is a laid-back blend of soulful, jazz-inflected EDM and hip-hop.

In reviewing "Shape the Future," MusicOMH said, "It is certainly his most adult record to date, complementing an output already crammed with staples that no self respecting chillout or hip hop DJ should be without."

Details: 8 p.m. Tuesday, June 12. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $20. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

6/14: John Butler Trio +

These Australian rockers have expanded from a trio to a five-piece, adding a keyboardist, percussion and a plus-sign to their name as they hit the road in support of the forthcoming followup to 2014's "Flesh and Blood."

The New Zealand Herald caught a recent show and raved, “This was a masterclass in musicality and an inspirational piece of soul-shine. Slap percussion groove, sliding, bending – stunning."

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, June 14. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $35. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/15: Frank Turner

The tour is in support of "Be More Kind," an album that finds him exploring new sounds. “I wanted to try and get out of my comfort zone and do something different,” says Turner, whose previous efforts positioned the folk-rocking punker as his generation's Billy Bragg.

The lead single, "Blackout," for instance, is as Turner says, "new territory for me, musically - a song you could even play in a club, it's about how we might collectively respond to social dislocation and collapse.”

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, June 15. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $35. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/17: Chicago / REO Speedwagon

Chicago will perform “Chicago II,” which included the singles “Make Me Smile/Colour My World" and "25 or 6 to 4," in its entirety followed by the “world’s longest encore,” as they jokingly refer to it, filled with greatest hits.

REO Speedwagon's set will be more of what fans would expect, including such staples as “In Your Letter,” “Can’t Fight This Feeling,” “Time For Me To Fly,” “Roll With The Changes,” “Keep On Loving You” and “Take It On the Run.”

Details: 7 p.m. Sunday, June 17. Ak-Chin Pavilion, 2121 N. 83rd Ave., Phoenix. $29.50-$329. 602-254-7200, livenation.com.

6/17: Gary Clark Jr.

Named "Best young gun" six years ago in Rolling Stone, this Austin guitarist has sent two consecutive albums, "Black and Blu" and "The Story of Sonny Boy Slim," to the Top 10 on the Billboard album charts, a rarity for blues.

Entertainment Weekly said of his latest effort, "Texas blues-guitar whiz Clark's second album is less flashy than his debut, but in pulling back on the guitar heroics, he galvanizes his genre-jumping, too."

Details: 8 p.m. Sunday, June 17. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $40-$150. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/18: Ninja Sex Party

“This is clearly going to be the best rock tour of all time,” says Ninja Sex Party frontman Danny Sexbang. “And if all these shows don’t sell out within the first 30 seconds, Ninja Brian will eat his own face on live TV.”

They're a comedy duo whose latest albums, "Under the Covers" and "Under the Covers, Vol. II," have featured them doing remarkably straight-faced, non-comedic, largely inessential covers of songs by Toto, Boston, Def Leppard, Asia and more.

Details: 8 p.m. Monday, June 18. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $30-$69.69. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

6/18: The Get Up Kids

The Kansas City rockers who gave the emo kids "Something to Write Home About" are back on the road in support of a brand new four-song EP titled "Kicker, their first new release since 2011’s "There Are Rules."

Singer-guitarist Matt Pryor says, “A lot of the songs early in our career were written in the perspective of being young and being in relationships and what we were going through then."

The new EP, he says, is "still a slice of life" inspired by their own experiences. They're just in a different place now – older, wiser and just as contagious.

Details: 8:30 p.m. Monday, June 18. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $27; $23 in advance. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

6/19: Post Malone

This white rapper's first single, "White Iverson," peaked at No. 14 on the Billboard Hot 100 on its way to going five-times-platinum. Subsequent hits include "Go Flex," "Congratulations," "Rockstar" and "I Fall Apart."

"Rockstar" was Malone's first No. 1 appearance on the Hot 100, logging eight weeks in the top spot. It was also the first song released from a second album called "Beerbongs & Bentleys." He's touring with 21 Savage, who guests on "Rockstar."

Details: 6 p.m. Tuesday, June 19. Rawhide, 5700 W. North Loop Road, Gila River Reservation. $48.50. 480-502-5600, rawhide.com.

6/19: New Found Glory

They've been called "the greatest pop-punk band in history" by Bad Religion's own Brett Gurewitz, who scooped them up for Epitaph after they walked out on Geffen.

After two albums on Epitaph, they switched to Hopeless for 2014's "Resurrection" and last year's "Makes Me Sick," which Alternative Press said "creates enough slight sonic diversions to give longtime fans something new to enjoy."

Details: 7 p.m. Tuesday, June 19. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $25-$45. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

6/20: Nipsey Hussle

Prior to launching his tour in support of the hit album "Victory Lap," the L.A. rapper held a sold-out release show at the Hollywood Palladium, which Billboard saluted as “less like a typical…rap performance and almost like a rock concert."

Hussle calls "Victory Lap" "a collection of my life stories, emotions and affirmations of ambition,” adding, “This is my most electric body of work and I'm more than excited to bring these songs to life in concert," the only place where the songs "can be fully experienced."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, June 20. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $30-$50. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

6/21: Slightly Stoopid

Signed by Bradley Nowell of Sublime while still in high school, these San Diego rockers have summed up what they do as a fusion of folk, rock, reggae and blues with hip-hop, funk, metal and punk.

"Meanwhile... Back at the Lab," became their second effort to go Top 40 on the Billboard album charts in 2015. They bring three modern-rock hits to the table - "2 A.M.," "Top of the World" and last year's "The Prophet." They're joined by Stick Figure and Pepper.

Details: 5:30 p.m. Thursday, June 21. Mesa Amphitheatre, 263 N. Center St., Mesa. $35. luckymanonline.com and mesaamp.com.

6/21: Shakey Graves

Alejandro Rose-Garcia had one decidedly unusual goal going into the making of the latest Shakey Graves release, the weirdly wonderful "Can't Wake Up."

"I wanted it to be vaguely 'Wizard of Oz'-themed, and I wanted it to be hectic and a little uncomfortable, like what I refer to as the Big Five Disney cartoons: 'Pinocchio,' 'Fantasia,' 'Snow White,' 'Dumbo' and 'Bambi,'" he says.

"All those movies are terrifying-some of the most stressful movies I've ever seen."

The end result is, not surprisingly, one very trippy ride through Rose-Garcia's rich imagination.

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, June 21. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $25. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/21: Stars

These Canadian indie-pop veterans are headed to town in continued support of last year's "There is No Love in "Fluorescent Light," which made the year-end readers' poll at Pitchfork.

Even Pitchfork's critic liked it, saying, "Stars stretch hushed electro-pop into scrambling arena rock, blending the Smiths’ guitar romance with bedroom soul like the product of some Mancunian Motown," adding that it finds them "just where they belong."

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, June 21. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $21-$38.50. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

PAST CONCERTS

3/21: Wolf Alice

These British rockers earned raves in 2015 for a stunning debut titled "My Love is Cool" on which they've done a brilliant job of underscoring Ellie Rowsell's ethereal vocals with arrangements that are alternately atmospheric and bathed in warm distortion.

And last year's "Visions of a Life" was even better. DIY Magazine called it "a gorgeously twisted beast that keeps Wolf Alice on the path to being Britain’s best band."

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, March 21. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $20-$23. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

3/21: Oddisee

The D.C.-based MC/producer and his bandmates arrive in continued support of “The Iceberg” and its live companion piece “Beneath the Surface.”

The album earned a perfect score from Rap Reviews, whose critic praised the rapper’s “depth of lyricism” as well as the “impressive flow” with which those lyrics are delivered.

Highlights range from “Things,” where he raps about how people tend to make themselves the center of the universe, to “Like Really,” a scathing social commentary aimed at white America.

Details: 8 p.m. Wednesday, March 21. Club Red, 1306 W. University Drive, Mesa. $18-$20. 480-258-2733, clubredrocks.com.

3/22: Howe Gelb

The Tucson legend's latest album, "Further Standards," is his second album in two years of "new piano standards," as he calls them, adding Lonna Kelley to several of the original tracks from "Future Standards" to complete the mood.

Two years into the project, Gelb says, "the material has taken on the sonic patina of precisely the intention of the title."

In addition to revisiting the song from "Future Standards" in a steamy London club, the album adds two newer standards to the mix.

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, March 22. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $15. thevanburenphx.com.

3/23: Kid Rock

It's the 20th anniversary of "Devil Without a Cause," his mainstream breakthrough, and Kid Rock is bringing his Greatest Show on Earth Tour to town in support of a forthcoming album called “Sweet Southern Sugar.”

It's the first album Kid Rock recorded in Nashville and it features spontaneous summer releases “Greatest Show On Earth” and “Po-Dunk,” as well as recent single “Tennessee Mountain Top.”

The album ranges from country to classic rock, with a little rap sprinkled in between. In other words, it is a Kid Rock album.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, March 23. Talking Stick Resort Arena, 201 E. Jefferson St., Phoenix. $34-$124. 602-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

PHOTOS FROM HIS PHOENIX STOP:

3/23: Johnny Mathis

The ageless crooner made his recording debut in 1956 with a self-titled album on Columbia Records.

In December, the label celebrated his 61 year anniversary by issuing "Johnny Mathis: The Voice of Romance," a stunning 68-disc box set that contains every album he released for the company.

And that's just long-players, meaning it doesn't include such classic singles as "Chances Are" and "The Twelfth of Never."

MORE:Singer Johnny Mathis on new box set, tour, possible autobiography

Details: 7 p.m. Friday, March 23. Celebrity Theatre, 440 N. 32nd St., Phoenix. $40-$132. 602-267-1600, celebritytheatre.com.

3/23: Rich the Kid

This rapper's breakthrough hit, “New Freezer,” which features a guest spot from Kendrick Lamar, and has sparked the “New Freezer Challenge,” a viral dance competition where fans have been uploading videos swaying to the song's beat.

In an interview with XXL, he said he signed to Interscope because "the label gave me the opportunity to take over the game completely and that's what I'm going to do." Now, he's gearing up to drop what he's convinced will be "the greatest album of 2018."

Details: 8:30 Friday, March 23. Marquee Theatre, 730 N. Mill Ave., Tempe. $50.50-$80.50. 480-829-0607, luckymanonline.com.

3/23: Sorority Noise

They took the emo scene by storm in 2015 with “Joy, Departed” a cathartic postcard from the edge that offered vivid insights into Cameron Boucher's real-life struggles with manic depression without romanticizing sadness.

Last year’s “You're Not As _____ As You Think” is every bit as powerful, inspired as it was by Boucher reeling from the death of several friends since the release of “Joy, Departed.”

The album was praised in Alternative Press, and deservedly so, as “an album that holds nothing back – musically nuanced but raw, explosive but restrained, matched only by the torrent of unapologetic emotion of Boucher’s subject matter.”

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, March 23. Nile Theater, 105 W. Main St., Mesa. $15-$18. www.niletheater.com.

3/23-25: Innings Festival

Chris Stapleton, Queens of the Stone Age and the Avett Brothers headline the inaugural Innings Festival at Tempe Beach Park, produced by C3 Presents, the team behind Lollapalooza and Austin City Limits Music Festival.

Counting Crows, Young the Giant, The Head and the Heart, Decemberists, Dispatch, Cold War Kids, Local Natives, Lord Huron, Sylvan Esso, Luke Combs, Citizen Cope, the Gin Blossoms, Eagles of Death Metal and Craig Finn are also performing.

As the title suggests, there's a spring training theme going on, which will include appearances by professional baseball players.

REVIEW:Innings Festival draws to a triumphant close

Details: 3 p.m. Friday and Saturday, March 23-24; 1:30 p.m. Sunday, March 25. Tempe Beach Park, 80 W. Rio Salado Parkway. $159 for a three-day pass; $89 Friday and Saturday; $95 Sunday. www.inningsfestival.com.

PHOTOS FROM THE FESTIVAL:

3/24: Cowtown's Phx AM Afterparty with Ho99o9

Experimental hip-hop crossed with hardcore punk and industrial rock gives this Jersey-based duo a sound all their own while providing the perfect backdrop for the explosive political broadside on "United States of Horror."

As Clash Music noted, the album is "wired on a different kind of anger – these tracks seethe with violence and disgust, raging at dark political orders, economic inequality, racial tension and fractured society.

Details: 8 p.m. Saturday, March 24. The Pressroom, 441 W. Madison St., Phoenix. $17-$20. 602-396-7136, thepressroomaz.com.

3/24: The Sword

How low can they go? The latest Melvins lineup features two new bassists for the low, low price of one. Singer-guitarist Buzz Osborne and drummer Dale Crover are joined on bass by Steve McDonald of Redd Kross and Jeff Pinkus of Butthole Surfers.

Why? Because they can. And because it sounds good. At least, that proved to be the case on "Pinkus Abortion Technician," their latest release, which features a sludge-metal rethink of the Beatles hit "I Want to Hold Your Hand."

Details: 8 p.m. Thursday, May 31. Crescent Ballroom, 308 N. Second Ave., Phoenix. $20. 602-716-2222, crescentphx.com.

6/1: Mega 104.3 Summer Jam

This '80s blowout is highlighted by female trio Exposé, who ruled the charts from '87 to '90 with tunes like "Come Go with Me," "Seasons Change" and "Your Baby Never Looked Good in Blue;" and pop diva Taylor Dayne ("Tell It to My Heart," "Love Will Lead You Back"). Also on board: Stevie B., Nu Shooz, Debbie Deb, Whodini and more.

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, June 1. Talking Stick Resort Arena, 201 E. Jefferson St., Phoenix. $30-$57.50. 602-745-3000, ticketmaster.com.

6/1: Calexico

These Tucson-based desert-rock icons are nine albums deep into a celebrated career, and they haven't stopped exploring new ideas, as amply illustrated on "The Thread that Keeps Us," this year's model.

As the Independent noted, "The intimacy and evocative atmosphere of previous releases has been retained, but there’s a fresh, barnstorming spirit brought by the team surrounding the core duo of Joey Burns and John Convertino."

Details: 8 p.m. Friday, June 1. The Van Buren, 401 W. Van Buren St., Phoenix. $25-$40. 866-468-3399, thevanburenphx.com.

6/1: The Monkees Present the Mike & Micky Show

Hey, hey, they're the Monkees. Or half of them anyway. Mike Nesmith and Micky Dolenz are bringing an intimate evening of hits, deep cuts and harmonies to Chandler.

Backed by a full band, the duo will touch on every era of their 50-year career, from "Last Train to Clarksville" to their 2016 Billboard Top 10 album, "Good Times."



In their first-ever tour as a duo, Nesmith and Dolenz will sing such classics as "I'm a Believer," "Daydream Believer," "Pleasant Valley Sunday" and "Listen to the Band."

Details: 7:30 p.m. Friday, June 1. Chandler Center for the Arts, 250 N. Arizona Ave. $48-$88. 480-782-2680, chandlercenter.org.

Take a team-by-team look at every high school football team in Bergen and Passaic counties:

Becton

Coach: Jack Maher (5th season)

Outlook: Becton can jump over .500 if it adjusts to a new quarterback and the move to a 4-4 defense. With only three seniors to replace, there's experience on both sides of the ball.

State of the Program:Becton football poised for bounceback year in 2019

State of the Program:Bergen Catholic football not resting on its laurels

Bergen Tech

Bergenfield

Outlook: The Bears have experience and the potential to score a winning season and North Group 3 playoff bid. Earning their first playoff win in decades is a stretch.

State of the Program:Bergenfield football shooting for elusive postseason win

Bogota

Coach: Brian Appleton (2nd season)

Division: NJIC Patriot

2018 record: 4-6

Players to watch: Ashanti Caviness, junior, WR/LB; Dayval Chimilio, senior, QB/LB; Robert Fabijanczuk, senior, OL/DL; Alex Melendez, junior, OL/DL; Stephen Papastefanou, senior, OL/DL; Devin Ramos, senior, OL/DL.

Outlook: The Bucs return a small number of juniors and seniors, so their success will be dependent upon the development of younger players and newcomers, as well as overall health.

State of the Program:Bogota football aims to surprise in 2019

Cliffside Park

Coach: Tom Mandile (3rd season)

Division: SFC Patriot Gold

2018 record: 4-5

Outlook: The Red Raiders are on the way up under Mandile, having increased their win total in each of his first two seasons. An experienced lineup will go for its first winning season of the decade.

State of the Program:Cliffside Park football on the rise under Tom Mandile

Clifton

Outlook: The Mustangs scored their first postseason victory in 12 years by advancing to the 2018 North 1, Group 5 semifinals. The program is starting to win the way it did during glory days of old, and its hope is to take the next step (at least) in the playoffs.

State of the Program:Clifton football aims for deep postseason run in 2019

Cresskill

Coach: Kevin Quinn (6th season)

Division: NJIC Meadowlands

2018 record: 5-4

Players to watch: Aidan Fuelner, senior, QB; Tim Coffey, senior, RB; Dan Ferrara, junior, OL/LB; Leo Urena, senior OL/DE; Kyle Henderson, junior, FS.

State of the Program:Cresskill football trending up for 2019

DePaul

The Spartans will be physical. Will they be as deep as the other North Jersey superpowers? No, but they don't use that as an excuse.

State of the Program:DePaul football continues to be a success story

Dumont

State of the Program:Can Dumont football break through in 2019?

Dwight Morrow

Coach: Joe Hoyle (1st season)

2018 record: 4-5

State of the Program:Dwight Morrow football focused on the future

Eastside

Coach: James Magazine (1st season)

Division: SFC Liberty Red

2018 record: 1-9

Players to watch: Samir Chapman, senior, FB/LB; Michael Jackson III, senior, QB; Ahsin Jacobs, sophomore, WR/DB; Jahsin Jacobs, sophomore, DE; Jadyn Kitchings, senior, WR/CB; Chris Santana, senior, WR/LS.

Outlook: It might be asking a lot for the Ghosts to gain ground in a tough division. Yet that doesn’t rule out a marked improvement, especially with the return of four players who were two-way starters as freshmen. Team speed is Eastside’s biggest asset.

State of the Program:Eastside football rebuilding its foundation

Elmwood Park

Coach: Tom Mulligan (6th season)

Division: NJIC Liberty
