search_result.title: Contentious $7.2M IR schools vote nears
search_result.text:
Gray Hughes

rghughes@dmg.gannett.com

Mark Steele has been around the Indian River School District a long time.

The interim superintendent is a graduate of the district and has either taught or been an administrator in Indian River since 1981.

During this time, there's never been a more important moment as when the district again tries to pass a $7.25 million expense referendum, he said.

That's kept Steele busy. The former assistant superintendent became interim superintendent when Susan Bunting was confirmed as education secretary in Delaware Jan. 24. Since then, he has heavily promoted the referendum, speaking with local groups, such as the Southern Sussex Rotary Cluband the Shore Democrats on why the referendum should pass. He even held a Facebook Live session all this month.

"By the time I get home from doing a faculty meeting, PTO meetings and referendum meetings, it's just a 12 to 13 hour day," he said. "With that said, I usually get to bed pretty quick."

But he believes it's all been worth it to increase funding.

If the referendum passes, it would raise taxes by 49 cents per $100 of assessed property value, bringing the rate to $3.068 per $100, which would raise taxes by $95.41 for the average taxpayer in the district.

The hotly debated expense referendum is being held to deal with rising student populations throughout the district, which has grown by 22.4 percent over the past 10 years. The district had 10,467 students as of September 2016.

At that pace, the district will reach 12,991 students by the year 2026.

If the referendum passes March 2, 33 cents of the 49 cents would go toward student enrollment growth, 8 cents for school security and 8 cents for student support and services, which would include textbooks, technology and student organization support.

This isn't the district's first try.

The first referendum failed by a mere 30 votes Nov. 22, 2016.

Similar to the previous vote, this referendum has faced pushback, too.

Those in opposition fear higher taxes and say the board does not deserve the money, citing recent financial issues by the district and former chief financial officer Patrick Miller.

BACKGROUND: Indian River referendum fails in razor-close vote

BACKGROUND: After audit, IRSD promises better financial practices

BACKGROUND: Indian River board approves second referendum

READ MORE: IR schools ask Indian River Fire Company for money back

Miller was placed on administrative leave in April 2016. In May 2016, an audit into the district's finances began. Soon after, Miller resigned.

The audit, released in November 2016, found financial misdoings it attributed to Miller, including accusations of bullying, writing checks to charities for which he served as president, and a general lack of institutional control.

Since then, Indian River School District residents have been given more of an opportunity to read the audit and fully come to terms with its contents, according to Sussex County Councilman Rob Arlett, R-5.

Arlett is confident in the direction the district is heading.

"I believe, and know, the leadership of the district has made some changes, and I think they have accepted the responsibility of the wrongdoing," Arlett said.

Not everyone is pleased, with many still skeptical about the district's financial practices.

With teachers' jobs on the line, a student population on the rise and the need for new schools in the future, the district has been in overdrive to persuade community members before the March 2 vote.

'You should resign'

Social media has been abuzz about the referendum, with those both for and against the referendum making their feelings known, mostly on Facebook.

This has even prompted Arlett, who created the "LOCALS ONLY-Bethany Beach, DE Area" group on Facebook, to return to monitoring the group's nearly 8,000 members' activity.

"It has become an emotional topic for all parties involved," he said. "And there have been a lot of thoughts on both sides."

Despite many attempts by The Daily Times to reach out to locals who have voiced opposition on Facebook and during public meetings, many declined to be interviewed.

But social media hasn't been the only outlet for those in opposition of the tax raise.

At a board meeting Jan. 31, emotions boiled over. Several people concerned with the direction of the district's finances spoke out against the board, prompting a response from the district the following day.

"I am all about a better education for our children because I have one sitting in this audience," said Dana Lathbury, a parent who sends her child to John M. Clayton Elementary School in Frankford, during the meeting.

"But where is the accountability when this gentleman took as much money as he did from this district, and we let him go? We let him walk … free. But you want to throw it back on our taxpayers."

Hillary Mitchell also spoke out about the district's handling of Miller.

She was concerned the district continues to pay Miller's pension, something the district says it is obligated to do, while asking for money from the residents of the district.

"How can this board have the audacity to ask the citizens to vote for a referendum giving the district more money while allowing the former CFO to retire and receive a pension?" she asked.

Many are concerned charges have not been brought against Miller. However, the Indian River Board of Education members said they are unable to bring the charges themselves, and the charges must come from the Delaware Attorney General's office. In the letter the following day, the district also explained the differences between paid and unpaid leave, and that the board does not control pensions.

"By law, our former CFO was entitled to his full pension and benefits at the time of his retirement," the statement read. "This was not a secretive process as has been alleged by some members of our community. To withhold benefits would have been a violation of the Delaware Code and exposed the district to possible legal repercussions."

Robert Maloney voiced his concerns with the board at the Jan. 31 meeting.

"You are publicly elected officials misusing public funds," he said. "You should resign."

Yet Steele remains steadfast as to why the referendum needs to pass.

He said a strong education system is key to having a strong community.

READ MORE: Indian River's 2nd referendum: Teachers' jobs at stake

"If you look at any strong community in the United States, you are going to see one thing: A strong community is always balanced by a strong education system. And if we struggle to get this through, it is going to be drastic to us what is going to happen in terms of cuts and the level of cuts," he said.

"That, in turn, will also reflect on the community, and if we are going to keep them both strong, we need to do everything possible to get this referendum passed."

Supportive "with concerns"

Raising taxes still has many concerned.

Arlett said he will support the referendum but has his eye on taxes and money coming into the district, especially from the state of Delaware and the federal government.

"This referendum, when it first came out, I was supportive, but with concerns," he said. "And I'm no different today."

He is not of fan of raising taxes, and thinks elected officials on the school board need to be transparent and accountable to the people in the community to manage taxpayer dollars as well as educate children.

He added he is not a fan of giving more money just for the sake of giving more money.

"I'm not automatically a fan of raising taxes and giving more dollars," he said.

But, to benefit the students in the Indian River School District, Arlett supports it.

Regardless of the March 2 outcome, more referendums may be in the future for district residents.

BACKGROUND: Public reaction to the first Indian River referendum mixed

In addition to the current referendum, another referendum will needed in the near future that also addresses the population rise in Indian River schools.

In April 2016, the district's school board submitted a certificate of necessity to the state of Delaware, which would allow construction of a new elementary school on the Ingram Pond property in Millsboro and a new middle school on the Sussex Central High School campus, along with adding about 32 classrooms to the high school. This was in addition to other school expansion projects.

Steele tried to alleviate concerns about a future referendum.

"The board is probably going to proceed with the Ennis school for the simple reason that it has no local funds attached to it," he said. "It is purely state funding."

Right now, he said, the current expense is at such a critical level, it would not make sense to be constructing the new buildings, which would require local dollars with the exception of the new Howard T. Ennis School.

He also added if the current expense referendum is not passed, there would be cuts to the budget that would make it impossible to staff any of the new schools.

READ MORE: Steele to take reins at IR if Bunting gets state post

READ MORE: Indian River referendum detailed at board meeting

Other budget cuts

District-planned events have not been the only forum for referendum discussion.

Businesses, political groups and pro-referendum Facebook pages have been held and created in the previous months.

At an event at Bethany Beach Books to give teachers in both the Indian River and the Cape Henlopen school districts free books, the referendum was not far from people's minds.

John Vogel, a fifth-grade teacher at Lord Baltimore Elementary School, said he would like to see the referendum pass to benefit the students.

"Without a doubt it's needed," he said. "If you look at what teachers do, a lot of things we do for our own students and classes comes from our own pockets. I am stealing supplies from my home to use in my classroom."

Andrew Carter, a parent of three students in the Indian River School District and a Selbyville resident, has volunteered as a parent ambassador to help pass the referendum.

Carter created an "IRSD Referendum Support Group" on Facebook on Jan. 18. The group posts information about why it feels the referendum should pass. Nearly 2,000 have joined the group in a month.

He said there is a cloud hanging over the district: budget cuts.

"Not passing the referendum, along with the budget cuts, would be a double whammy," he said. "That makes this referendum more critical to pass to support the growth."

The state of Delaware will be making cuts to all school districts to ensure the state budget is balanced, which Steele said could impact the Indian River School District anywhere between the minimum of $1.2 million (1.25 percent) and the maximum of $9.5 million (10 percent).

And, if the referendum does not pass, 10 percent of jobs across the board would have to be cut, with teachers being the last cut that would have to be made, he said.

Steele said because of this, voters have a big decision.

Voting will take place from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. March 2. Those living in the district — renter or homeowner — who are 18 and older can cast their vote at East Millsboro Middle, Georgetown Elementary, Indian River High, Long Neck Elementary, Lord Baltimore Elementary or Selbyville Middle schools.

Rep. Ruth Briggs-King, R-37, hopes for a good turnout at the polls.

For a decision like this one, it is important people make their voices heard, the Sussex Central graduate said.

"It is their school district," she said.

READ MORE: Teachers staying in droves in coastal Delaware schools

Arlett said he has noticed residents within the Indian River School District have been more engaged during this referendum compared to the one held in November 2016.

Steele agreed, and added he is confident.

The 13-hour days are paying off for him, he said.

Talking with those in the district, he is able to tell them his vision of future growth, success and transparency.

The harm in not passing this referendum would affect students, Steele said. He tells voters they should leave emotions at home while voting.

"You have to weigh what the increase is and what the benefits are compared to the pitfalls of it not passing," he said.

search_result.title: Traffic, tourism concerns for Lewes Village Center
search_result.text:
Phil Davis

pdavis3@dmg.gannett.com

The proposed shopping center for development on Kings Highway outside Lewes could cause significant traffic congestion and impact the city's tourism and commercial industries, according to a new report.

Authored by consulting group Environmental Resources Management, the report both criticizes developers Jack Lingo LLC and JG Townsend Jr. & Co. for their proposed The Village Center, a 1100-parking space shopping center at the intersection of Kings Highway and Gills Neck Road currently being reviewed by county officials.

The report reads: "Given the location of planned and potential Study Area development, US (Route) 9, US (Route) 9 Business, and Gills Neck Road, among other roads, are almost certain to experience significant traffic increases."

"In the case of the Kings Highway segment of US (Route) 9, such traffic volume increases could exceed the road's carrying capacity, potentially causing a degraded or even failing Level of Service," it continues.

The group claims the developers need to use more predictive traffic studies for their applications, saying a 2006 state Department of Transportation study that outlined expected increases in traffic due to the nature's growth did not accurately summarize how much the area is changing and how it would be effected. It asks the state to require more models to be completed with forecasts into 2030 before accepting the developers' application.

A checkered past

Presented at a Nov. 30 meeting held by Lewes officials, the city-commissioned report comes after a number of years in which the developers and Sussex County officials fought about the use of more than 30 acres of undeveloped land.

Back in 2008, the two developers approached the county with plans to create a 521,000-square-foot shopping center but withdrew the application after the county's Planning Commission voted unanimously to recommend denial.

A downsized, 387,000-square-foot version was submitted but rejected by the Sussex County Council in January 2010. The developers sued the county, saying its reasoning was not supported by evidence and that Councilwoman Joan Deaver, D-Lewes, should've recused herself from the vote because of her alleged involvement with an opposition group.

Eventually, after the appeal was shifted to U.S. District Court, a stay was issued from Aug. 5, 2014, through May 25, 2015, and eventually extended to the end of the year, to allow the developer to submit a new rezoning application to the county.

The impact of traffic

Jack Lingo LLC has said the idea is to make the area more walkable, with ideas for a grocery store, pharmacy and dry cleaner as part of the overall plan.

Expert: Mental health of man accused in PV murders diminishing

But the report claims that the developers are using outdated numbers to justify their layouts and planning. Environmental Resources Management said the 2006 study does not take into account the rising population of Cape Henlopen High School, also on King's Highway, as well as planned housing developments to be completed in upcoming years.

"The combined traffic from the Village Center and other surrounding developments are likely to cause the Savannah Road/Gills Neck Road/Front Street intersection to exceed capacity (to "fail" in transportation planning terms) more frequently throughout the year and throughout the day," the report reads.

"Such failures would be most common during weekday peak hours, and, given the current distribution of weekend daily traffic in Lewes, for extended portions of weekend days," it continues. "Because the intersection is at the heart of the City's historic district, prolonged traffic congestion here could likely impact tourist and other commercial activity in the historic district."

Developer's Response

In a statement on behalf of Jack Lingo LLC, spokesman Doug Motley claimed "The draft ERM report contained several inaccuracies (for example — the actual number of units in several nearby subdivisions are lower than those published in the report)."

Motley also noted how the report did not include a full analysis of DelDOT's 2006 traffic impact study nor the study's "review letter, and resulting letter agreement" which outlined "multimillion dollars of roadway improvements required as a result of their analysis."

Concerning traffic on Route 9, Motley said the 2006 study, as well as the agreement for necessary improvements, provide the solutions to questions raised by Environmental Resources Management about the road's level of service. He pointed toward an agreement with DelDOT to improve the intersection of Gills Neck and Clay roads as an example of how the report did not understand the full picture.

"DelDOT's required improvements directly relate to what capacity is needed to what capacity is needed to provide acceptable levels of service," Motley said.

City officials still have concerns as to the impact the project could have to the city overall.

Lewes council's Vice President Fred Beaufait said that there are further concerns given the city's limited evacuation routes.

Beaufait said there are "only three ways into and out of Lewes," with flooding regularly happening on New Road, one of the three.

With Route 9 also acting as one of those three, the idea of having a major shopping center that would attract traffic could hinder residents' ability to leave the town quickly in the case of a flood or severe weather event.

"We are somewhat locked in in terms of being able to evacuate," Beaufait said. "If we put this shopping center on King's Highway, now we've got one way in and out of Lewes."

search_result.title: Concerns raised about Sussex's true colors
search_result.text:
James Fisher

The News Journal

Resident%3A %27It%27s just a horrible stigma for the county%27

Wilson and Phillips have defended their decision

Sussex County has high-tech companies and highly-ranked schools. It boasts vibrant tourism and agricultural sectors, with towns retirees flock to and chickens its farmers grow exported around the world. Its population is on the rise, and its county government hasn't raised property taxes in 25 years.

But those pleasantries were not on people's minds last week when they thought about Sussex County; instead, it was bigotry. The County Council found itself ensnared in controversy after two council members, Sam Wilson and Vance Phillips, gave offense to the NAACP, describing it in a May 13 meeting as an organization fixated on race and prone to discriminate against anyone who isn't black. They also withheld $100 apiece in discretionary grants to the group's local chapter.

Given the opportunity to explain his stance one week later at the next meeting, Wilson instead stirred up more controversy by noting that "three homosexuals" had stepped forward to defend the NAACP.

NAACP members and others delivered forceful rebuttals at the next meeting, noting that the episode had put a magnifying glass on Sussex County's reputation as the most resistant part of the state to embrace social changes that swept America in the civil rights era and beyond.

"Sussex County has long been considered one of the most prejudiced counties in the state of Delaware," Jane Hovington, president of the Lower Sussex Branch NAACP, said sternly to the County Council. "What has always been mere conjecture has been given credence by your recent statements."

In interviews and public comments, Wilson and Phillips have defended their decision to express unease about the NAACP and adamantly rebuffed accusations that doing so signaled they hold bigoted beliefs. Holding to a common pattern of modern racial dust-ups, they accused their accusers of being the ones not seeing past the color of their skin.

"To make judgments of people when you don't know them is evil, really. Worst thing you can do," Wilson said Tuesday. "I'm sure not a racist, and my parents were not racists."

But Wilson, in the same talk to reporters Tuesday, promptly gave his opponents another opening to paint him as out of touch with the modern era.

In the same week that Pennsylvania, Oregon and Washington, D.C. opened doors to gay marriage, Wilson was noting disdainfully that "three homosexuals" came to the Sussex County Council meeting to show support for the NAACP, and explaining why it was he'd once told a Delaware gay marriage advocate, Lisa Goodman of Equality Delaware, she was bound for hell.

"I said if she didn't change her lifestyle, she's probably going to wind up there," Wilson said. "That's very plain in Romans. I mean, I don't make the rules."

It is difficult to imagine an elected official in Kent or New Castle counties saying that without instigating a voters' revolt.

But Sussex – split between the rural, agricultural western side and its more liberal beach towns like Lewes, Rehoboth Beach and Dewey Beach along the coast – is a different story.

That such comments are electorally acceptable here bothers Delawareans who wish Sussex County – especially the conservatives and Republicans whose electoral grip is strongest west of U.S. 113 – would have decisively shed its song-of-the-South reputation by now.

"I don't think incidents like what happened two weeks ago help the image of Sussex County any," said Joe Conaway, a former county administrator. "It plays into the view of – and I hate this word – progressives who think the people of Sussex just climbed out from under rocks. And that's not the case."

On Saturday the county government, responding to a request for comment on the two-week-long controversy, gave a statement from County Council President Michael Vincent that said "the recent events surrounding the Sussex County Council are unfortunate."

"They have taken the focus off the many important functions of county government and the hard work of our dedicated staff, and they have caused strife in our community. This is not what our county stands for, nor will it be its legacy," Vincent said. "Like any other organization that comes before Council seeking support, the Lower Sussex NAACP Youth Council should have received the highest levels of respect during the May 13 meeting."

Neil Dickerson Sr., who moved to Millsboro several years ago from Maryland, said "it really gives Sussex County a horrible, horrible name."

Dickerson said "it's gone viral" now.

"It's just a horrible stigma for the county," he said. "You talk about a good old boy issue, there it is."

But others watched what happened and decided Wilson and Phillips had simply tweaked a too-little-questioned consensus on race.

"He's saying these people are concentrated on race instead of letting things go," Marion Barton, 79, said of Wilson. "Years ago, people didn't even think about that [race]. Now anything that anybody says, people are afraid to say anything back against them. I think this guy needs some support."

Part of a pattern

The "good old boy" stigma goes beyond race and includes a division between the haves and have nots.

Dickerson, who volunteers helping elderly residents, said the NAACP comments aren't the only problem. He said an older woman in Rehoboth replaced an old shed with a new one of the same size on the same footprint but it took her years to resolve it with the county.

Meanwhile, he said, people with real estate connections breeze through the system.

"We need change," he said.

The county government has found itself fending off accusations of hard-heartedness toward the poor and minorities before.

In 2012, the county agreed to have its liability insurer pay $750,000 to a developer who'd tried to build low-income housing near Laurel, but was stymied by rulings of the Planning & Zoning Commission and the County Council.

In 2010, during a public hearing on the development, a county resident stood up to say when his mother "found out all these people was gonna be back there, she was scared to death. ... I have nothing against these people. But I know how it's going to be. I better not catch them hunting on my land."

Those comments, the U.S. Department of Justice later said, "were impliedly derogatory and based on stereotypes of African-American and Hispanic residents," and the DOJ maintained the county government needed to have done more to make clear its denials of the developer's proposal weren't rooted in the same biases. As part of a settlement agreement with the Department of Justice to halt the fair-housing lawsuit, the county must submit its decisions on like-minded issues to federal authorities for final approval.

The County Council has also spent years litigating its members' ability to begin meetings with prayers while still staying within the bounds of the Constitution's establishment clause. Four county residents sued them over the constant invocation of The Lord's Prayer, and in 2012, a settlement agreement allowed the council to substitute a different prayer, the 23rd Psalm, while the plaintiffs agreed to drop their lawsuit.

The fight brought years of litigation and attention to the question of whether Sussex County Council respected the beliefs of non-Christians. Phillips and Wilson, in recent weeks, have called attention to a recent U.S. Supreme Court ruling that widened the scope of acceptable legislative prayer practices, saying the council should consider re-opening its Lord's Prayer litigation.

"It seems like we're the only body right now that's not permitted to do this. And it kind of irritates me a little bit," Wilson said on May 13. "I think we'd be fine to go ahead and say The Lord's Prayer, or ask someone to go up and pray if they wanted to. I don't see any holdback."

Since the 2012 settlement, the council members had not often heard a challenge to their prayer practice, but for the past two weeks an atheist from Seaford, Robert C. Harrison, has used public-comment periods at their meetings to protest their focus on prayer issues.

"Many Christians have exhibited prejudice against non-believers and discriminate against them socially," Harrison said. "By holding Christian prayers here, you are helping them to identify those with differing beliefs. You are preventing some of those that fear identification from attending."

Outside the council chambers, Wilson in particular has tangled repeatedly with gay rights advocates, bringing up his fervent belief that devout Christianity is incompatible with being gay. When the Cape Henlopen School District's school board deadlocked on a vote to add an elective class on Bible literacy, Wilson said to a talk-radio host that "one of them is a lesbian," and "they're not very strong on the Bible."

"Thank God for the western side of Sussex," he went on. "We still believe in our Bible."

For some Republicans, including many outside of Sussex, the comments coming from council members this week about the NAACP and gay people brought feelings of chagrin and dismay.

"Any kind of divisive language that drives people away from the party is not helpful," said John Fluharty, executive director of the Delaware Republican Party. "It's OK to have differences with folks, but we've got to build a coalition. This harsh language has just got to stop. ... I refuse to allow my party to be held hostage and bullied any longer by reactionary forces who try to hide their bigotry behind the mask of conservatism."

Fluharty said he's concerned employers considering whether to invest in Sussex County could take a dimmer view of the prospect because of the controversies.

"They've got business down there. They've got thriving tourism. At what point does this begin to impact all that?" Fluharty said. "At what point do potential employers look at the situation there and say, we don't want to relocate."

Vincent, in his statement Saturday, said he hoped potential residents and investors would "view Sussex County from the broadest of perspectives. There is no doubt they will see a community that is inviting to anyone who wants to realize their part of the American dream."

Former Sussex resident Til Purnell, who now lives near Charlottesville, Virginia, said the latest controversy is really nothing new.

Purnell recalled a different County Council years earlier where one of the members, the late William Stevenson, shut her down when she tried to speak at a meeting. Instead, the councilman suggested she should be at home canning.

That comment, too, brought a string of bad press.

"I think they were disrespectful to all women," she said.

She suspects council members still are because they are still part of that "good old boy network."

"Poor old Joan Deaver. She puts up a gallant fight," Purnell said of the lone female on council.

For black citizens, it was even worse than for women, Purnell said.

They were essentially ignored ... "treated like pet dogs. You don't harm them. You just put them out in the shed" rather than pay attention to them, she said.

Room for all?

In Rehoboth Beach, where tourism is the economic driver, Carol Everhart, chief executive officer of the Rehoboth Beach-Dewey Beach Chamber of Commerce, said "any negative statement or anything that's perceived as a negative statement tends to get a lot of attention."

But going into the busy Memorial Day holiday weekend, "we are solidly booked," she said.

"Rehoboth is a biblical term and it means room for all," she said. "That's the best kind of image you can have."

At the south end of the boardwalk Friday, dozens of gay visitors took in the sunshine on a picture perfect beach day.

Louis Panos, of Baltimore, said he has always felt welcome in the city – perhaps more so than in Baltimore where people are often segregated into neighborhoods that are specifically black or gay.

"I feel extremely comfortable," he said.

Panos said he's only driven through western Sussex County on his way to the beach, with his only stops used to get gas.

Meanwhile, openly gay County Clerk of the Peace John Brady said he hopes he isn't remembered as the county's first openly gay elected official.

Instead, he wants people to say: "He did his job and he continues to do his job."

Brady said he has known Sam Wilson for 12 years – back to the time when they were both Republican candidates. Brady has changed his party affiliation.

"Sam is a man of principle," Brady said. "He's not a flip-flopper."

Brady recalled sitting down at the Wilson family kitchen table with Sam, his wife and one of his sons – then a candidate for the Indian River School Board. Brady said he talked to them about how to get elected.

In fact, prior to his successful run for Sussex County Council in 2008, Wilson was a perennial Republican candidate.

"He and his wife are actually really nice folk," Brady said, adding that "this county has a lot of colorful people."

Yet Brady acknowledges that not everyone in the county is inclusive.

Sometimes when people come into the Clerk of the Peace office, they say they'd prefer to have "a Christian marry them," he said.

Brady, who said he was raised Catholic, said he's interpreted that to mean: "someone who's not gay."

His office has three people who perform marriage ceremonies so they are able to accommodate the request.

"I've gotten over that," he said.

Changing county

If you wanted to identify the Sussex County Republican least like Sam Wilson, it might be Ernie Lopez.

In his first term as a state senator in the 6th District, representing Lewes, Milton and Rehoboth Beach, he beat a Democrat in a district where Democrats outnumber Republicans. He has cast votes in favor of repealing the death penalty and for limitations on firearms purchases, votes a good number of Sussex conservatives critiqued.

He did vote against legalizing gay marriage, surprising some who note he represents Rehoboth Beach, traditionally a popular place for gays and lesbians to vacation and own second homes. But as he campaigned in 2012, he opposed a state constitutional amendment that would have prevented the legislature from considering a gay marriage bill at all.

In an interview, Lopez quickly distanced himself from Wilson's and Phillips' NAACP words.

"I don't think the comments that were made were reflective of the majority of individuals in the county – Republicans, Democrats, anyone," he said. "We all need to take a step back when we hear those comments."

At the same time, he said, he disputed the notion that Sussex is behind the times on racial issues.

"This county and this state have been so good to me and my family. I can say that as someone whose last name doesn't pop up in the phone book too often," Lopez said. "As the first Hispanic in the Delaware State Senate coming from Sussex County, I know we've come a long way. But there's still a long way to go."

Tim Dukes, a Laurel pastor and first-term representative in the state legislature, represents Wilson-Phillips country, on the western side of Sussex. But Dukes said he couldn't get behind the two councilmen's position on the NAACP.

"It does nothing to promote what our county is about and what we stand for," Dukes said in an interview Friday. "I hope that as a county we have matured enough, and we care enough about one another, that we look past race."

Richard Smith, president of the Delaware NAACP, delivered some of the most fiery criticism of Wilson and Phillips last week.

"I'm trying to understand what came out of your mind to make you say the things you said," Smith said at Tuesday's council meeting. "It's either racism or hate. Which is it?"

In a radio interview on Delmarva Public Radio later in the week, Smith attributed the controversy the comments caused, in part, to the changing demographics of Sussex County, saying the county was increasingly led by its more urbanized, less rural eastern populace.

"What's happening is folks are coming in from D.C, Virginia, and they're coming from New York, and they're moving into Sussex County. So the county is changing," Smith said. "And this little group of people who don't want the change is fighting everything. It's going to be a long fight."

Many Sussex Countians, black and white, still have vivid memories of when their hometowns were rigidly segregated by race. J. Everett Moore Jr., an attorney who represents Sussex County's government and attends council meetings, published a book in 2012, "Growin' up Country," that did not shy away from documenting segregation.

"When integration occurred, Georgetown was the last segregated high school because the blacks in Georgetown were allowed to continue their high school at Jason," an all-black high school, Moore wrote. "Although blacks attended Georgetown High School when I was in high school, there were none in my grade until my senior year in 1968." He also recalled summer holidays at Trap Pond, in Laurel, when blacks and whites stayed on different shores of the pond.

White people in Moore's world then, he wrote, perceived racial discord as a problem elsewhere, but not in Sussex.

"Everyone agreed that the 'colored' people around here were good people who didn't want to riot or create problems," he wrote of mainstream white sentiment in the mid-1960s. Moore credited a high school teacher of his, Bill Davis – a Nanticoke Indian – with opening his eyes to the damaging effects of segregation. "Many of us were shocked by what he said," Moore wrote.

Many blacks in Sussex County saw it differently from the start. Jea Street, a New Castle County Council member who went to Georgetown to admonish Wilson and Phillips, told them he remembered traveling through the county with his grandfather as a child.

"I have no memories of joy when he had to come over here, to go through this Circle, to transact his business because of the way he was treated," Street said. "I've tried to forget that as a child we weren't allowed to go to Rehoboth Beach. We had to go to Lewes Beach. As much as I wanted to delude myself and think that things have changed, your statements make it crystal clear that nothing has."

Phillips, in comments after the boisterous public comment period on Tuesday, said like Wilson, he believed he'd done the right thing in being skeptical of the NAACP chapter's worthiness for a county grant. He also acknowledged the episode had raised hackles.

"Maybe apologies, at some point, would be worthy all around," Phillips said. "But in this heated environment, I don't think you're going to get it from anybody."

Conaway, the retired county administrator, said he didn't think this month's controversy would put a dent in the Sussex County way of life.

"I think everybody can grow from it," Conaway said. "I haven't noticed the traffic heading south being any lighter. The attraction to come to Sussex is the natural resources God gave us. That's why they come."

Molly Murray contributed to this story.

Contact James Fisher at 983-6772, on Twitter @JamesFisherTNJ or jfisher@delawareonline.com.

search_result.title: 'The traffic is us': Sussex grapples with transportation as county grows
search_result.text:
CORRECTION: This story has been updated to correct the name of the applicant of the rezoning request in Lewes that could potentially have 165 multi-family apartment units.

When Sussex County councilman George Cole told a roomful of homeowners he voted against their community, it wasn't because he didn't like them.

The Peninsula, a sprawling 800-acre community of over 1,400 homes in Millsboro, was a "great community," Cole said in a recent phone interview, but too dense and out of character with the area, "larger than three-fourths of the small towns in this county."

He told the property owners earlier this year, "Folks, I wish half of you weren't here."

Cole is at the center of a debate — one that could have lasting effects on southern Delaware's upsurge in traffic — as the council plans for Sussex County's next 27 years in its comprehensive plan: Should the council allow more housing units per acre to reduce sprawl, or stick to the low-density status quo?

Sussex is the fastest growing county in Delaware. The population has doubled since 1990, statistics show.

Southern Delaware is a vacation home mecca, with over one-third of the housing units here deemed vacant.

Background:Sussex traffic worsens with growth in housing, jobs, tourism

The housing market on the eastern side caters especially to retirees and second-home buyers, local realtors say. Bethany Beach realtor Leslie Kopp said in her market, inventory is half of what it was just two years ago.

At the Peninsula meeting earlier this year, to which Cole said he was late due to traffic, a man asked matter-of-factly, "You guys approve development. Why don't you stop it?"

The Peninsula was approved in November 2002 as a residential planned community for medium density housing, including condominiums. Cole was the sole "Nay."

When the council approved The Peninsula 16 years ago, the comprehensive plan had predicted the county would swell to 73,292 households by 2020: In 2016, there were already over 83,000.

Over 40 percent of single-family homes here are less than 20 years old. Last year's fiscal year saw 2,269 new dwelling permits issued, and residential property sales topped 5,000 in 2017.

Less than 20 percent of all land in Sussex County, including parcels listed under protected status, is developed. That leaves 256,000 acres of land that are either undeveloped or farmed.

As more people stay at the beach beyond summertime tourism, car-dependent sprawl fans out into areas lacking public transportation, shopping centers and roads that accommodate increased traffic.

Many officials are calling for moderate infrastructure improvements, like putting in longer turning lanes, connecting commercial parking lots, adding additional lanes and widening shoulders — fixes that could have been made 10 or 20 years ago, Cole said.

"Those are the simple things we should be requiring," he added.

But a recent 3-2 vote against Overbrook Town Center, a sprawling shopping center that would have been built in a residential area between Milton and Lewes, shows the county council's near-even divide over rezoning, density and commercial and mixed-use development.

It's no surprise that a resort area on the Atlantic Ocean within a three-hour drive of Washington D.C., Baltimore and Philadelphia could attract such an influx. That geographic proximity is what makes Sussex County unique, and what makes more people come, year after year, temporarily and permanently.

Cole, who is considering stepping down this year as council member after 36 years, is focused on the folks who currently live here year-round, those most impacted by increased development and subsequent traffic.

"We’re at capacity," he said, "and I just question, is it good to keep piling on?"

Density and mixed use, debate

Joe Conaway's single-family home on a spacious corner lot in Georgetown is the picture of low-density suburbia and the Sussex County status quo.

But it's not Conaway's ideal model for the future of Sussex County.

He describes himself as pro-growth, and as a land use consultant who has represented large communities like The Peninsula, he ought to be.

"Smart growth to me is density," the former county administrator said. Following the county's low-density scripture of two housing units per acre in agricultural-residential zones forces more development, than, say, allowing four units to the acre.

"In order to get to 400 units, I've got to do another 200 acres," Conaway said. "So all I do is go down the street and keep building, until we're way out in the county where nobody wants (the houses) to be."

Sussex County councilman and U.S. Senate candidate Rob Arlett said he supports certain densities in specific locations, though not necessarily to the scale of Sea Colony, which was approved when the county allowed 36 units per acre.

While Cole has argued higher density projects will contribute to more traffic, Arlett says the same about single-family homes.

"No matter what we do it’s not going to change people’s desire to come here," Arlett said, questioning what will happen if the county keeps saying yes to just two housing units per acre.

"It will be a continuation of what’s been happening, and that’s called sprawl," he said, adding that more farmland gets eliminated with current development standards and people are pushed onto the back roads. "That exacerbates the issue."

But the issue isn't just density, Arlett said: It's increasing housing types like apartments and condominiums, and putting them near existing public transportation and infrastructure.

Cole said developers are primarily building single-family developments "because that's what the market is," but Arlett wants to bring in affordable housing, which doesn't necessarily equate to detached homes on a half-acre lot, especially in eastern Sussex.

The Lewes City Council voted 4-1 on June 11 to approve a request to rezone a seven-acre lot to mixed residential.

The request was submitted by OA Vantage Point II, LLC and is comprised of Greg Stevens, Vantage Point and Ocean Atlantic President Preston Schell.

The parcel, located off Savannah Road, could contain 165 multi-family apartment units priced for working folks, as presented by Schell Brothers for a conceptual site plan.

The parcel, located off Savannah Road, could contain 165 multi-family apartment units suited for working folks, as presented by Schell Brothers for a conceptual site plan.

Councilperson Dennis Reardon said he thinks there is a need for workforce housing, especially for Beebe Hospital and Cape Henlopen High School employees.

"While there will be a traffic impact, I don’t think it will be that great," he said.

According to councilperson Rob Morgan, those who spoke against the rezoning request were concerned with density and traffic, especially since it could generate more vehicle trips on Savannah Road.

But Reardon said the apartments would give people a place to live in Lewes and thus less time on the road.

Related:Live where you work, unless at the beach. Affordable housing slim at resorts

More people, even those who can't afford a $300,000 single-family home, can get their housing slice, according to Conaway. It will just take more density and mixed-use development, which may also help residents drive less miles to get to shopping, nightlife and other amenities that improve quality of life.

Delaware Department of Transportation planning director Drew Boyce said the agency supports mixed-use development. Integrated residences and businesses are part of Sussex County's history, he added.

"When we first came here and started settling, everything was mixed together," Boyce said. "The general store, housing and restaurants were all on the same block."

Then the county created zoning districts, which Boyce said serves a purpose for separating incompatible industries like loud manufacturing businesses from neighborhoods.

"But what's wrong with having a school in a residential area, or a food service provider?" he said. "Those types of mixed use we encourage."

Transportation, issues in the past

Transportation and development are at an all-time high now, but the roadside affair has been ongoing for over 40 years now.

Conaway remembered fighting the “continuous battle” for better roads back in the 1970s during his time as county administrator.

He testified on the floor of the state senate and told legislators Sussex County needed relief from traffic congestion.

An upstate senator, whom Conaway declined to name, told him, "Look, it's a 100-day season. Get used to it." Now, the summer season's congestion is spreading into the rest of the year as more people fall in love with Sussex County so much they decide to live there.

"The opportunity to correct some of the road problems is slowly diminishing," Conaway said

"You didn't notice there were a lot of cars? You didn't notice that we are a large tourist industry?" Conaway asked, figuratively pointing at the newcomers who complain about traffic at county meetings.

Story continues after graphic

DelDOT doesn't have to build a bunch of new roads, Conaway said. Rather, it should better utilize existing ones by renumbering them and redirecting people to them.

In the 70s, during Conaway's time as county administrator, the state suggested building a new Route 26 south of Bethany Beach, one that would have involved seven major acquisitions.

"The people raised hell: 'We'll never need that kind of road. It'll never happen,'" Conaway recalled. "Well, it did."

Boyce mirrored Conaway's observation, saying many proposals to expand major corridors like Route 26 and Route 9 were "met with a lot of opposition," halting projects to improve major links to Sussex County's transportation system.

More:Five Points traffic nightmare: Officials search for a fix

More:Senior transportation expands in Sussex County

Part of it may have been DelDOT's fault in how they communicated projects, but that's changing, according to Boyce.

"We're getting folks to see the future and where we're going, now that the future is in their front yard," he said. "Folks are realizing you can't just do nothing. No is no longer an answer to the transportation issues."

Overbrook and mixed use

A young Joe Biden, who was just starting his career as a senator in 1973, came up to Joe Conaway after a town meeting, wanting to talk to him.

They went down to his office and Conaway asked, "What's the problem?"

"You've got to stop this development," Conaway remembers Biden saying. "You've got to do something about all this traffic and growth."

"And I said to him, 'I'll do it. I'll get fired, and people are going to be mad,' " he recalled. " 'But you answer one question for me: Who's the last person on the beach? Give me their name. Who's the last person here?'"

Forty-five years later, the last person is yet to be determined in Sussex County, and Conaway's land consultancy business is still representing incoming developments.

Overbrook Town Center, a recently rejected project that Conaway provided his services to, in its most recent manifestation would have been a 312,000-square-foot shopping center in front of a residential development called Overbrook Acres with 135 homes on 66 acres.

The project, which would have been located on Cave Neck Road just off Route 1, met massive public opposition. Nearby residents voiced concerns about quality of life, the environment and of course, traffic.

More:Sussex officials say no to rezoning farmland on Del. 1 for Overbrook Town Center

More:Overbrook Town Center: What to know about the revote

Despite the updated mixed-use proposal, the developers were rejected by a 3-2 vote.

"Overbrook was designed to bring regular shopping to Sussex County," Conaway said. "The things you go to Salisbury and Dover to get, that's what would have been there."

While the future of the parcel is yet to be determined, it may become what it was zoned for: residential housing, no more than two units to the acre.

"We can’t keep saying yes to single-family homes and keep saying no to commercial," Arlett said. "You need commercial to support those (people) buying the homes."

Millsboro example, looking to future

Not everyone says no to growth.

Millsboro grew in population by 12 percent from July 2016 to June 2017, according to the town's website. It issued the highest number of residential permits in the county between 2011 and 2016. And it prides itself in being a "truly pro-business, pro-family town."

"If you're not growing, you're dying," town manager Sheldon Hudson said. "We want to find a way for the town to embrace the positive aspects of development."

Developments in Millsboro like Plantation Lakes carry a mix of housing options, from single-family homes to villas and townhomes, which arguably cost much less in Millsboro than they would near the beach.

Hudson is a proponent of "work where you live," and calls place-making "huge." He often uses the tagline, "the convenience of a city but the charm of a small town," when describing Millsboro.

More:Millsboro says plan to draw business, residents is working

More:Millsboro hopes to build restaurant boom downtown

Retirees and millennials have at least one thing in common: They want to do as much as they can in the place they live, Hudson said.

And if Millsboro can attract enough of a mix of people, from millennials to retired folks, from hospitality workers to health care professionals, it could end up creating a mixed-use environment, where services are in close proximity to residences.

But it doesn't work if higher density development is not within walking or biking distance.

"(George) Cole is right in that if it's truly not dense and diverse enough to have commercial reasonably close to residential, then you just end up in a smaller space," Hudson said.

Public transportation works "much better" in higher density, urbanized areas like Wilmington, Boyce said. Having more regular riders means DelDOT can provide a more reliable bus service.

"Density in the middle of nowhere doesn’t help anybody," Boyce said, echoing Cole. "But if we can cluster higher density developments in and around existing transit routes, that allows us to potentially increase the frequency of those transit routes and provide a better service."

Sussex County Council is in discussion for a potential pilot program that would be located in a geographic area not completely built out yet, Arlett said.

It could serve as Sussex County's mixed-use trailblazer.

The area would include "all types of housing" and commercial development near residences. Arlett calls the test an "opportunity to plan for the future."

For now, as tourists squeeze their way into the resorts this summer, Cole is determined to accomplish one feat: Keep the traffic moving.

"We will be defeated if we get gridlock on a regular basis and it just comes to a halt," Cole said, adding that proposed solutions need to ensure the roadways don't become a parking lot.

"Nothing is worse than being stuck in gridlock. That kills me," Cole said. "If I’m creeping along, I’ve got hope."

tgoebel@delmarvanow.com

Traffic by the numbers

Between 2001 and 2016

•Route 16, a two-lane east-west highway, saw an 82 percent increase in traffic. On average, 6,330 vehicles per day use that road, which runs through Milton to Route 1.

•Route 1, a four-lane highway that often backs up during peak vacation times, registered an increase of 58 percent in both directions north of Route 16, carrying an average of 32,871 vehicles daily.

•Route 24 between Millsboro and Route 1 had a 70 percent increase, with an average of 19,308 vehicles daily.

•Route 9 at the infamous Five Points had a 24 percent increase while the same two-lane road had a 63 percent increase west of Georgetown, where it crosses Route 113.

•Route 404 west of 113 — a favorite of beach-going tourists — had an increase of 45 percent, carrying an average of 29,819 vehicles daily.

•Route 113, another favorite of vacationers traveling north and south, had an astounding 112 percent increase. The four-lane road carried 38,505 vehicles daily.

•Route 26, Garfield Parkway, declined by 17 percent, possibly because construction activities.

•Route 54, a busy east-west highway in the southern part of the county that runs through Selbyville, saw a modest increase from 6,269 vehicles daily to 6,869 from 2010 to 2016. Locals often complain about traffic on the route and DelDOT could not explain the discrepancy between residents’ perceptions and their own data.

Winter is growing

•On Route 113 between routes 9 and 404, February traffic in 2010 averaged 13,034 vehicles per day in 2010 but that volume increased 101 percent to 26,163 in 2016.

•By contrast, the July 2016 daily volume was just 19 percent higher — 31,184 vehicles.

•Route 113 traffic in February 2016 was 26,163, marginally lower than the summertime peak of 31,184 vehicles. In 2010, the differences were markedly different — 13,034 vehicles in February, 32,723 in July.

search_result.title: Southern Delaware Roller Derby: Women who roll with brutal purpose
search_result.text:
Betty ClockHer raced around the track, coming face-to-face with a scrum of women on skates clogging her passage. She had seconds to make a decision.

The jammer for Southern Delaware Roller Derby juked one way, then leaped over a blocker with acrobatic grace to avoid being stopped and scored five points for her team.

That kind of physical action and savvy skating was front and center at the Dover Skating Center when her team hosted River City Roller Derby from Richmond, Virginia.

With nonstop physical action and names like Betty ClockHer, Brute E. Licious, Hello Killy and Prim N Popher, Southern Delaware's version of roller derby is every bit as entertaining as the leagues made popular by TV in the 1980s and 90s.

There's one difference, though. The women who skate for Southern Delaware Roller Derby are the real deal.

Back in its TV glory years, roller derby resembled and had a following much as professional wrestling does today.

The sport included staged action and storylines, and the most popular was called RollerGames, which featured a figure-8 shaped banked track, dancers and stunts like the sudden-death alligator pit (with real reptiles).

On Saturday against River City, it was just two teams battling it out for superiority.

There were player pileups, acrobatic skating and a lot of physical action from start to finish of the bout, which is two 30-minute periods. Included in the action were multiple 30-second penalties for illegal actions like blocks to the back, tripping or throwing elbows.

With exotic makeup, face paint, multicolored leggings and even spiked belts to accentuate the uniform, the "RollerGirls" pulled off the bad girl image perfectly.

That's the trademark of the team and roller derby matches in the Women's Flat Track Derby Association, said Andrea Davis, whose derby name is Double Treble because she's a choir teacher and singer by trade.

"It's fun, but physically grueling," said Davis, a veteran member of four years. She is taking time off from skating to have a child (called a nine-month injury in roller derby vernacular) in November. "It's a full-contact, hard-hitting sport. It's not for the faint of heart."

The names given some of the moves can be just as entertaining as the game itself, such as booty block, the can opener, cannonballing, butt to the gut, hip whip, seal clubbing and the soul crush, to name a few.

And should some of the moves and rough play result in injury, the referees are quick to stop the action. Emergency medical technicians are present at every game to check the downed player while the other participants take a knee.

While the recent bout was non-sanctioned and was played to get the newest members of the combined Southern Delaware team experience, the action was rough and tumble.

SODEL and Diamond State Roller Derby out of Christiana (founded in 2006) are the only sanctioned leagues from Delaware in the 417-league Women's Flat Track Derby Association worldwide organization.

Since its inception in April 2011, the Dover team has grown to include 25 to 30 skaters who make up two home teams that essentially go by the same name. One is a sanctioned "travel" team consisting of the league's best players, while the other is made up of newer, less experienced skaters.

The sanctioned bouts count toward the team's ranking, and there is a four-bout minimum to maintain accreditation in the organization.

Players on both teams have an opportunity to participate in home bouts, as well as travel to play other teams. SODEL has traveled to West Virginia and Connecticut and will skate in New York and Ohio later this year. The team's next bout is Aug. 11 against Charm Female Trouble out of the Baltimore/Washington area at the Dover Skating Center.

Besides the skating members, the team has many league members who don't skate but do behind-the-scenes things. More than 15 sanctioned officials, many with names just as entertaining as the skaters, oversee the action.

When she's on the track, Davis is no different than the others who let their alter-egos and competitive natures take over.

"Some of us grew up playing traditional competitive sports and were looking for that same type of rush," she said. "We're not looking to kill each other out there, but everybody is here to play as hard as they can, for as long as they can."

If the jammers are fast and physical, the scores can be high. In the Saturday bout, Betty ClockHer (Jamie Doerfler), Brute E. Licious (Caitlyn Short) and Prim N Popher (Alicia Kendoeski) provided all the firepower the team needed for a 304-106 win.

A PRIMER: The basics of roller derby scoring

A growing family

SODEL is a skater-run, skater-owned nonprofit organization. Davis said since its start, the following has grown and each bout is a production with an announcer, volunteers keeping score and selling merchandise and others selling raffle tickets for various charities.

When the league started, the team skated out of the Milford Skating Center and had a pretty large following from Sussex County. That has grown since the team started skating out of Dover, she said.

"We are still drawing spectators from the southern part of the state," Davis said. "In addition, our friends from Smyrna and Middletown and southern New Castle (County) are making the short trip."

Kasey Bennett, one of the regular skaters who sat out Saturday's bout to give the newer players a chance to gain more experience, said the roller derby scene is a subculture.

She said the reason the sport is growing is the "wow factor."

"Getting them in the door the first time is the trick," said Bennett, a six-year veteran called Racey Anthony on the track. "Once they are in, I have never heard anyone say anything other than that was more competitive, hard-hitting, exciting and athletic than I ever thought it was going to be. They are pleasantly shocked and come back."

That's the case for Brute E. Licious' grandmother Arlene Evans and her friend John Jeffries, who make it to every home bout. The fans are affectionately known as "Bleacher Creatures."

"I couldn't believe how rough they get," Evans said. "I was afraid of her (Brute E. Licious) getting hurt, but it's so exciting. I love it."
